revision.comment: /* See also */ adding list of yokozuna
revision.text:
The following are the events in professional [[sumo]] during 1987.
==Tournaments== *Hatsu [[honbasho|basho]], [[Ryōgoku Kokugikan]], [[Tokyo]], 11 – 25 January *Haru basho, [[Osaka Prefectural Gymnasium]], [[Osaka]], 8 – 22 March *Natsu basho, Ryōgoku Kokugikan, Tokyo, 10 – 24 May *Nagoya basho, [[Aichi Prefectural Gymnasium]], [[Nagoya]], 5 – 19 July *Aki basho, Ryōgoku Kokugikan, Tokyo, 13 – 27 September *Kyushu basho, [[Fukuoka International Centre]], [[Kyushu]], 6 – 20 November
==News==
===January=== *25: [[Chiyonofuji]] wins his twentieth ''[[yūshō]]'', becoming the third man after [[Taiho Koki|Taihō]] and [[Kitanoumi]] to reach this landmark. He defeats fellow ''[[yokozuna (sumo)|yokozuna]]'' [[Futahaguro]] in a playoff after both men finish on 12–3. Futahaguro had beaten Chiyonofuji in their regulation match but could not do so a second time. Although this is his sixth runner-up performance, his first top division championship continues to elude him. ''[[Sekiwake]]'' [[Konishiki]] scores 10–5 and wins the Outstanding performance prize for his wins over both yokozuna. [[Masurao]] wins the Technique Award. Former ''[[komusubi]]'' [[Ōyutaka]], who lost ''[[sekitori]]'' status in 1985, announces his retirement. He assumes the Arashio ''[[toshiyori]]'' or elder name and stays on as a coach at his stable.
===March=== *22: [[Ōzeki]] [[Hokutoumi]] wins his second championship with a score of 12–3, finishing one win ahead of stablemate Chiyonofuji and Konishiki on 11–4. New ''[[komusubi]]'' Masurao has a superb tournament, defeating two ''yokozuna'' and four ''ōzeki'' in the first seven days and is awarded the Outstanding Performance prize. [[Hananoumi]] wins the Technique prize and [[Tochinowaka Kiyotaka|Tochinowaka]] the Fighting Spirit Award. Futahaguro drops out on the tenth day. In jūryō [[Takamisugi]] wins the ''yūshō'' while [[Kaiki Nobuhide|Kaiki]] announces his retirement. He stays in sumo as Takashima Oyakata.
===May=== *24: Ōzeki [[Onokuni]] wins his first ''yūshō'' with a perfect 15–0 record. He is the first man other than Chiyonofuji to win in the Ryōgoku Kokugikan which opened over two years before in January 1985. Runner-up is Hokutoumi on 13–2, who is promoted to ''yokozuna'' after the tournament. [[Kokonoe stable]] becomes the first since [[Takasago stable|Takasago]] in 1949 to have two active ''yokozuna'' simultaneously. Konishiki is also promoted to ''ōzeki'' after a fine 12–3 score, becoming the first foreigner ever to reach sumo's second highest rank. He wins the fighting spirit prize while the other ''sekiwake'' [[Asahifuji]] gets the Technique prize. Masurao has another giant-killing tournament and wins another Outstanding performance prize. The ''jūryō yūshō'' is won by [[Onohana]]; the ''[[makushita]]'' championship by [[Akinoshima]]. Former ''sekiwake'' [[Kaneshiro Kofuku|Kaneshiro]] (also known as Tochihikari) retires rather than face demotion to ''makushita''. Unable to obtain elder stock, he leaves the sumo world.
===July=== *19: After an unremarkable 10–5 last time out, Chiyonofuji wins the ''yūshō'' in style with a 14–1 record. Ōnokuni turns in another good performance, finishing runner-up on 12–3. New ''yokozuna'' Hokutoumi wins eleven bouts and new ''ōzeki'' Konishiki is on 9–6. Futahaguro can manage only 8–7. Ōzeki [[Wakashimazu]] retires, leaving [[Futagoyama stable]] without anyone in ''[[san'yaku]]'' for the first time in 15 years. Also announcing his retirement is [[Hattori Yuji|Hattori]] (also known as Fujinokawa), a former amateur champion who was plagued by injuries in his four years as a professional. Special prizes are awarded to Asahifuji for Technique, Tochinowaka for Outstanding Performance and [[Dewanohana Yoshitaka|Dewanohana]] for Fighting Spirit. Veteran former ''sekiwake'' [[Masudayama]] wins the ''jūryō'' championship.
===September=== *27: Hokutoumi wins his first championship as a ''yokozuna'' with a 14–1 record. His only defeat is to Ōnokuni, whose 13–2 runner-up performance earns him promotion to ''yokozuna'' as well. [[Asahifuji Seiya|Asahifuji]] is simultaneously promoted to ''ōzeki'' after scoring 12–3 and winning Technique and Fighting Spirit prizes. Konishiki also finishes in third on 12–3. [[Sakahoko]] is awarded the Outstanding Performance prize for his defeat of Chiyonofuji on Day 6. (Chiyonofuji later withdrew from the tournament because of injury.) The lightweight ''jūryō'' veteran [[Hachiya Toshiyuki|Hachiya]] retires and becomes Onogawa Oyakata.
===November=== *22: Chiyonofuji returns from injury to win his 22nd yūshō with a perfect 15–0 record (his fourth). Futahaguro has his best performance for some time, finishing runner-up on 13–2 alongside Hokutoumi. Ōnokuni can manage only 8–7 in his ''yokozuna'' debut. Sakahoko wins his second Outstanding performance prize in a row — he had defeated two ''ōzeki'' and a ''yokozuna'' in the first three days. [[Tochitsukasa]] receives the Technique award. [[Nankairyu]] from [[Western Samoa]], only the third non-Japanese to reach the top division, scores 8–7 on his debut in ''[[makuuchi]]''. Former ''sekiwake'' [[Hō'ō Tomomichi|Hō'ō]] wins the jūryō division ''yūshō'' for the fourth time.
===December=== *31: Futahaguro is forced to retire by the [[Sumo Association]] after a heated argument with his stablemaster (former ''sekiwake'' [[Osamu Annen|Haguroyama]]) four days earlier led to him storming out of the stable, allegedly slapping his boss's wife on the way.<ref>{{cite web|title=Wrestler Gives Sumo Tradition A Big Kick Into 20th Century|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1988-01-11/news/8803210309_1_wrestlers-stable-japan-sumo-association|publisher=Chicago Tribune|accessdate=26 September 2012|date=January 11, 1988}}</ref> He becomes the first ''yokozuna'' ever to be forced out of the sumo world.<ref>{{cite book|title=Grand Sumo|author=Sharnoff, Lora|publisher=Weatherhill|year=1993|isbn=0-8348-0283-X|pages=60}}</ref>
==Deaths== *27 September: Kataonami Oyakata (former sekiwake [[Tamanoumi Daitaro]]), aged 64.
==See also== *[[Glossary of sumo terms]] *[[List of past sumo wrestlers]] *[[List of years in sumo]] *[[List of yokozuna]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Years in sumo}}
[[Category:Years in sumo]] [[Category:1987 in sports|Sumo]]

revision.text:
The Belgian [[Association Football| football]] fraud investigation, also known as ''Operation Zero'' officially<ref name="Bisschop Interview">{{Cite interview |last=Bisschop |first=Eric |interviewer=Xavier Taveirne |title=De Ochtend |url=https://www.vrt.be/vrtnws/nl/2018/10/26/voetbal/ |work=De Ochtend |publisher=[[Radio 1 (Belgium)|Radio 1]] |date=2018-10-26 |access-date=2018-10-26}}</ref> and ''Operation Clean Hands'' informally ([[Dutch language|Dutch]]: ''Operatie Propere Handen''), is a federal investigation conducted by the [[examining magistrate]] of [[Limburg_(Belgium)|Limburg]], on behalf of the Belgian Federal Public Prosecutor's Office. The investigation is concerned with [[organized crime]], [[money laundering]] and private corruption ([[bribery]]) in Belgian football, [[Belgian First Division A|division 1A]] and [[Belgian First Division B|division 1B]] specifically. Started in late 2017, the investigation raised to national prominence on October 10, 2018, when 44 house searches were carried out across Belgium and 14 more house searches internationally. 29 suspects were arrested in Belgium, and 4 more abroad. Of the 29 arrested in Belgium, 20 were charged with one or more crimes.<ref name="D1/026/18">{{Cite web |url=https://www.om-mp.be/nl/article/press-release-federal-public-prosecutor-s-office-d102618-0 |title=Press Release by the Federal Public Prosecutor’s Office - D1/026/18 |date=2018-10-11 |access-date=2018-10-12 |institution=Federal Public Prosecutor’s Office}}</ref><ref name="Sporza Overzicht">{{Cite news |url=https://sporza.be/nl/2018/10/12/overzicht-fraudedossier/ |title= 21 mensen in verdenking in fraudedossier van Belgisch voetbal |date=2018-10-16 |access-date=2018-10-16 |publisher=[[Sporza]] |language=Dutch}}</ref> During the weeks following the raids, 3 additional suspects were arrested and criminally charged.<ref name="Maes">{{Cite news |url=https://www.vrt.be/vrtnws/en/2018/10/23/fresh-arrest-in-money-laundering-and-match-fixing-probe/ |title=Fresh arrest in money laundering and match fixing probe |date=2018-10-23 |access-date=2018-11-12 |publisher=[[Vlaamse Radio- en Televisieomroeporganisatie|VRT]]}}</ref><ref name="Camus">{{Cite news |url=https://www.vrt.be/vrtnws/nl/2018/11/07/voetballer-fabien-camus-vrijgelaten-door-onderzoeksrechter-in-vo/ |title=Voetballer Fabien Camus vrijgelaten door onderzoeksrechter in voetbalschandaal |date=2018-11-07 |access-date=2018-11-07 |publisher=[[Vlaamse Radio- en Televisieomroeporganisatie|VRT]] |language=Dutch}}</ref><ref name="Maeschalck">{{Cite news |url=https://www.demorgen.be/sport/ook-makelaar-evert-maeschalck-in-verdenking-gesteld-in-belgisch-voetbaldossier-be75e9c9/ |title=Ook makelaar Evert Maeschalck in verdenking gesteld in Belgisch voetbaldossier |date=2018-11-07 |access-date=2018-11-07 |publisher=[[De Morgen]] |language=Dutch}}</ref>
== Background == Following the ''[[Ye Zheyun|Ye]] affair'' in 2005, the [[Belgian federal police]] launched the Sports Fraud Cell, a department of the Central Office for the Repression of Corruption (OCRC). Jointly managed by the Federal Public Prosecutor and the OCRC, the main task of the department is to gather and corroborate intelligence concerning sports fraud, corruption and match-fixing. If deemed necessary, an investigation is launched by the federal police.
In early 2017, the Sports Fraud Cell received a report from the Belgian [[Financial Intelligence Unit]] concerning suspicious activity through tens of bank accounts in bank office in [[Genk]]. As these transactions were connected to the [[Belgian First Division A]], the Sports Fraud Cell launched an investigation. In late 2017, the report of the investigation was passed to the federal police and the Federal Public Prosecutor.<ref name="Bisschop Interview"/><ref name="D1/026/18"/>
== Investigation == The investigation broadly consists of three components: two parts relating to money laundering and fraud, and a third relating to potential match-fixing. Two player agents, [[Mogi Bayat]] and Dejan Veljkovic, would have set up, independently of each other, a scheme to hide commissions from Belgian authorities. These payments included commissions on player transfers, player and manager wages, and other payments. During the investigation of these schemes, indications of possible [[Match fixing in association football|match-fixing]] arose. The match-fixing pertains to at least two relegation matches in [[2017–18 Belgian First Division A|competition season 2017-2018]].<ref name="D1/026/18"/>
On November 12, after the high profile arrests were made, the [[Court of Appeal (Belgium)|Court of Appeal]] of Antwerp removed examining magistrate Joris Raskin from the investigation. The recusal was requested by Hans Rieder, the lawyer of referee Bart Vertenten. Rieder argued that Raskin could not be impartial and independent because he was part of the Licensing Commission of the [[Royal Belgian Football Association]] until March 2018, months after the investigation started. Although Raskin himself and the Public Prosecutor disagreed, the Court of Appeal did find Rieder's request compelling.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vrt.be/vrtnws/en/2018/11/12/magistrate-removed-from-match-fixing-investigation/ |title=Magistrate removed from match-fixing investigation |date=2018-11-12 |access-date=2018-11-12 |publisher=[[Vlaamse Radio- en Televisieomroeporganisatie|VRT]]}}</ref> Following the verdict of the Court, Rieder argued for the immediate release of his client Vertenten.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vrt.be/vrtnws/nl/2018/11/12/advocaat-hans-rieder-meneer-vertenten-moet-op-staande-voet-vri/ |title=Advocaat Hans Rieder: "Meneer Vertenten moet op staande voet vrijgelaten worden" |date=2018-11-12 |access-date=2018-11-12 |publisher=[[Vlaamse Radio- en Televisieomroeporganisatie|VRT]] |language=Dutch}}</ref> Indeed, 4 days after the Court ordered the recusal, Vertenten was released on conditions and he resumed his main job as [[radiologist]] at the University Hospital [[UZ Brussel]].<ref name="Vertenten Released">{{Cite news |url=https://www.vrt.be/vrtnws/en/2018/11/16/referee-bart-vertenten-liberated-from-prison/ |title=Referee Bart Vertenten released from prison |date=2018-11-16 |access-date=2018-11-20 |publisher=[[Vlaamse Radio- en Televisieomroeporganisatie|VRT]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.vrt.be/vrtnws/nl/2018/11/19/bart-vertenten-blijft-aan-de-slag-als-radioloog-in-het-uz-brusse/ |title=Vertenten en Delferière, de twee verdachte scheidsrechters in voetbalschandaal, opnieuw aan het werk |date=2018-11-19 |access-date=2018-11-20 |publisher=[[Vlaamse Radio- en Televisieomroeporganisatie|VRT]] |language=Dutch}}</ref>
On November 20, Dejan Veljkovic, widely regarded as a key suspect in the investigation, signed a [[plea deal]] with the prosecution. As part of the plea deal, Veljkovic will serve a [[suspended sentence]] of 5 years and pay a (suspended) fine of 80,000 euros. Additionally, all illegally acquired assets will be seized by the government.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.vrt.be/vrtnws/nl/2018/11/20/persconferentie-kris-luyckx/ |title=De deal van Veljkovic: 5 jaar met uitstel en een boete van 80.000 euro in ruil voor alles wat hij weet |date=2018-11-20 |access-date=2018-11-20 |publisher=[[Vlaamse Radio- en Televisieomroeporganisatie|VRT]] |language=Dutch}}</ref> Although informal plea deals were used before, Veljkovic was the first to sign a deal where specific sentence reduction is assured by prosecutors. A law allowing these formal agreements was instated only months before the arrests, in August 2018, meaning Veljkovic is the first official ''spijtoptant'' in Belgian history. According to the law, a ''spijtoptant'' is suspect able to provide "substantial, revealing, sincere, and complete information" about serious crimes, e.g. organized crime or terrorism. In exchange for this information, the ''spijtoptant'' can get a more lenient sentence. Following the deal, Veljkovic was released on strict conditions.<ref name="Veljkovic Released">{{Cite news |url=https://www.vrt.be/vrtnws/nl/2018/11/20/veljkovic/ |title=Spelersmakelaar Veljkovic sluit deal met gerecht in ruil voor strafvermindering en wordt eerste spijtoptant in België |date=2018-11-20 |access-date=2018-11-20 |publisher=[[Vlaamse Radio- en Televisieomroeporganisatie|VRT]] |language=Dutch}}</ref>
== October 10, 2018 searches == {{Location map many | Belgium | width = 300 | float = left | caption = Searched club headquarters | alt = Searched club headquarters | label1 = [[RSC Anderlecht|Anderlecht]] | lat1_deg = 50.8347999 | lon1_deg = 4.2965755 | label2 = [[Club Brugge|Bruges]] | lat2_deg = 51.1941207 | lon2_deg = 3.1769832 | label3 = [[KRC Genk|Genk]] | position3 = right | lat3_deg = 51.0049835 | lon3_deg = 5.5320128 | label4 = [[KV Kortrijk|Kortrijk]] | lat4_deg = 50.8302393 | lon4_deg = 3.2483349 | label5 = [[KV Mechelen|Mechelen]] | lat5_deg = 51.0372404 | lon5_deg = 4.4852254 | label6 = [[KV Oostende|Ostend]] | position6 = top | lat6_deg = 51.2161677 | lon6_deg = 2.8873762 | label7 = [[Sporting Lokeren|Lokeren]] | lat7_deg = 51.116303 | lon7_deg = 3.9844204 | label8 = [[AA Gent|Ghent]] | position8 = left | lat8_deg = 51.0156076 | lon8_deg = 3.7310134 | label9 = [[Standard de Liège|Liège]] | lat9_deg = 50.60996 | lon9_deg = 5.5393013 }} On October 10, 2018, the federal police searched 44 buildings across Belgium, mostly focused on football club headquarters and suspect's residencies. The headquarters of [[RSC Anderlecht]], [[Club Brugge]], [[KRC Genk]], [[KV Kortrijk]], [[KV Mechelen]], [[KV Oostende]], [[Sporting Lokeren]], [[AA Gent]], and [[Standard de Liège]] were searched. During these searches, documents and contracts pertaining to player agents Mogi Bayat and Deljan Veljkovic were seized. 3 luxury watches were seized as well. Simultaneously, residences of club board members, player agents, referees, a former lawyer, journalists and a manager were searched. Further raids occurred at an accountancy bureau and 2 jewelry stores. During these raids, empty luxury watch boxes valued at 8 million euros, jewels, luxury watches, and cash were seized. As a result of these searches, 28 people were arrested, most of them very early in the morning.<ref name="D1/026/18"/>
[[File:Map Of Europe With Belgium France Luxembourg Serbia Montenegro Macedonia Cyprus Marked.png|thumb|Countries where searches were performed.]] Internationally, 14 locations were searched in 6 other countries: [[France]], [[Luxembourg]], [[Cyprus]], [[Montenegro]], [[Serbia]], and [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]]. During these searches, coordinated by [[Eurojust]], documents and assets on bank accounts and in safes have been seized, for a total amount of 3.6 million euros. No arrests were made during the searches at banks and a company in Luxembourg.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.wort.lu/de/sport/festnahmen-im-belgischen-fussball-durchsuchungen-in-luxemburg-5bbe036a182b657ad3b952cd |title=Festnahmen im belgischen Fußball, Durchsuchungen in Luxemburg |date=2018-10-10 |access-date=2018-10-12 |publisher=[[Luxemburger Wort]] |language=German}}</ref> In Cyprus, a 52 year old man was arrested on a European arrest warrant, with extradition procedures underway. More than 15 Cypriot police officers, and two Belgian investigators were involved in the searches of four properties in [[Nicosia]] and [[Famagusta]], where four computers, two laptops, two iPads, and documents were seized.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.financialmirror.com/news-details.php?nid=35966 |title=FOOTBALL: Cyprus arrest as part of Belgium match-fixing raids |date=2018-10-10 |access-date=2018-10-12 |publisher=[[Financial Mirror]]}}</ref> Six locations in the cities [[Belgrade]] and [[Niš]], Serbia, were searched, resulting in the seizure of up to €800.000 which allegedly originated from organized crime in Belgium. Uros Jankovic, business associate of Dejan Veljkovic, was also arrested Wednesday in Belgrade and ordered to be extradited.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://sport.blic.rs/fudbal/evropski-fudbal/ekskluzivno-blic-saznaje-policija-u-srbiji-zaplenila-800000-evra-prljavog-novca-od/3qvlqtf |title=EKSKLUZIVNO! "Blic" saznaje: Policija u Srbiji zaplenila 800.000 EVRA "PRLJAVOG" NOVCA od fudbalskih nameštaljki u Belgiji! |date=2018-10-10 |access-date=2018-10-12 |publisher=[[BLIC]]| language=Serbian}}</ref> 4 people were arrested during these international searches, and 2 European arrest warrants were issued.
In total, 184 Belgian and 36 foreign police officers participated in the searches, in Belgium and abroad.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.vrt.be/vrtnws/en/2018/10/10/police-raid-club-brugge-and-anderlecht/ |title=Police raid Club Brugge and Anderlecht as part of wider match-fixing and money laundering investigation |date=2018-10-10 |access-date=2018-11-12 |publisher=[[Vlaamse Radio- en Televisieomroeporganisatie|VRT]]}}</ref>
Because of the size and scope of the investigation, as well as the number of suspects arrested after the searches, up to 3 examining magistrates were working concurrently to process those arrested. Multiple examining magistrates being assigned to a single investigation is very unusual in Belgium, with the exception of terrorism cases.<ref name="Sven Mary Criticism">{{Cite news |url=https://www.vrt.be/vrtnws/nl/2018/10/12/heeft-advocaat-sven-mary-gelijk/ |title=Heeft advocaat Sven Mary gelijk met zijn kritiek op het voetbalonderzoek en de verschillende onderzoeksrechters? |first=Dominique |last=de Graaf |date=2018-10-12 |access-date=2018-10-10 |publisher=[[Vlaamse Radio- en Televisieomroeporganisatie|VRT]] |language=Dutch}}</ref>
== Charges == Throughout the investigation, 23 people were accused of one or multiple crimes. 14 were released on conditions and 6 were released without conditions. Among those charged are player agents, referees, club executives and board members, journalists, players, and managers.<ref name="D1/026/18"/> {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |- ! scope="col" | Accused ! scope="col" | Charge(s) ! scope="col" | Status |- ! scope="row" | {{Sortname|Mogi|Bayat}}, [[Sports agent|player agent]] | [[Criminal organisation]], [[money laundering]] | Released on conditions<ref name="Bayat, Denis, Steemans">{{Cite news |url=https://www.vrt.be/vrtnws/nl/2018/11/27/laatste-verdachten-in-voetbaldossier-komen-vrij/ |title=Laatste verdachten in voetbaldossier, onder wie makelaar Mogi Bayat, mogen vrijkomen onder voorwaarden |date=2018-11-27 |access-date=2018-11-27 |publisher=[[Vlaamse Radio- en Televisieomroeporganisatie|VRT]] |language=Dutch}}</ref> |- ! scope="row | {{Sortname|Marija|Bogojevska|nolink=1}}, Dejan Veljkovic's wife | [[Criminal organisation]], [[money laundering]] | Released on conditions<ref name="Mejjati, Siljanoski, Bogojevska">{{Cite news |url=http://www.standaard.be/cnt/dmf20181115_03946822 |title=‘Schone Handen’: twee spelersmakelaars en vriendin Veljkovic vrijgelaten |date=2018-11-15 |access-date=2018-11-20 |publisher=[[De Standaard]] |language=Dutch}}</ref> |- ! scope="row | {{Sortname|Fabien|Camus}}, ex-[[KV Mechelen]] player | [[Criminal organisation]], [[money laundering]] | Released on conditions<ref name="Camus"/> |- ! scope="row" | {{Sortname|Sébastien|Delferière}}, [[Referee (association football)|referee]] | [[Criminal organisation]], [[money laundering]], private corruption ([[bribery]]) | Released on conditions<ref name="Sporza Overzicht"/> |- ! scope="row | {{Sortname|Laurent|Denis|nolink=1}}, Mogi Bayat's attorney | [[Criminal organisation]], [[money laundering]] | Released on conditions<ref name="Bayat, Denis, Steemans"/> |- ! scope="row | {{Sortname|Dirk|Huyck|nolink=1}}, [[chairman]] of [[Waasland-Beveren]] | [[Criminal organisation]], private corruption ([[bribery]]) | Released on conditions<ref name="Sporza Overzicht"/> |- ! scope="row | {{Sortname|Peter|Maes}}, former manager of [[K.S.C. Lokeren Oost-Vlaanderen|Lokeren]] | [[Criminal organisation]], [[money laundering]] | Released on conditions<ref name="Maes"/> |- ! scope="row | {{Sortname|Karim|Mejjati|nolink=1}}, [[Sports agent|player agent]] | [[Money laundering]] | Released on conditions<ref name="Mejjati, Siljanoski, Bogojevska"/> |- ! scope="row | {{Sortname|Walter|Mortelmans|nolink=1}}, [[Sports agent|player agent]] | [[Criminal organisation]], private corruption ([[bribery]]) | Released on conditions<ref name="Sporza Overzicht"/> |- ! scope="row | {{Sortname|Dragan|Siljanoski|nolink=1}}, [[Sports agent|player agent]] | [[Money laundering]] | Released on conditions<ref name="Mejjati, Siljanoski, Bogojevska"/> |- ! scope="row | {{Sortname|Olivier|Somers|nolink=1}}, majority shareholder of [[KV Mechelen]] | [[Criminal organisation]], [[money laundering]], private corruption ([[bribery]]) | Released on conditions<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.vrt.be/vrtnws/nl/2018/10/30/voetbal/ |title=Voetbalschandaal: Mede-eigenaar KV Mechelen, Olivier Somers, komt vrij onder voorwaarden |date=2018-10-30 |access-date=2018-10-30 |publisher=[[Vlaamse Radio- en Televisieomroeporganisatie|VRT]] |language=Dutch}}</ref> |- ! scope="row | {{Sortname|Thierry|Steemans|nolink=1}}, [[financial director]] of [[KV Mechelen]] | [[Criminal organisation]], [[money laundering]], private corruption ([[bribery]]) | Released on conditions<ref name="Bayat, Denis, Steemans"/> |- ! scope="row | {{Sortname|Olivier|Swolfs|nolink=1}}, [[financial director]] of [[Waasland-Beveren]] | [[Criminal organisation]], private corruption ([[bribery]]) | Released on conditions<ref name="Sporza Overzicht"/> |- ! scope="row | {{Sortname|Thomas|Troch|nolink=1}}, [[Sports agent|player agent]] | [[Criminal organisation]], private corruption ([[bribery]]) | Released on conditions<ref name="Sporza Overzicht"/> |- ! scope="row | {{Sortname|Stefaan|Vanroy|nolink=1}}, [[sporting director]] of [[KV Mechelen]] | [[Criminal organisation]], [[money laundering]], private corruption ([[bribery]]) | Released on conditions<ref name="Sporza Overzicht"/> |- ! scope="row | {{Sortname|Dejan|Veljkovic|nolink=1}}, [[Sports agent|player agent]] | [[Criminal organisation]], [[money laundering]], private corruption ([[bribery]]) | Released on conditions<ref name="Veljkovic Released"/> |- ! scope="row | {{Sortname|Bart|Vertenten|nolink=1}}, [[Referee (association football)|referee]] | [[Criminal organisation]], private corruption ([[bribery]]) | Released on conditions<ref name="Vertenten Released"/> |- ! scope="row | {{Sortname|Frank|Dekeyser|nolink=1}}, journalist for [[Het Laatste Nieuws]] | [[Criminal organisation]], private corruption ([[bribery]]) | Released without conditions<ref name="Sporza Overzicht"/> |- ! scope="row | {{Sortname|Stijn|Joris|nolink=1}}, journalist for [[Het Laatste Nieuws]] | [[Criminal organisation]], private corruption ([[bribery]]) | Released without conditions<ref name="Sporza Overzicht"/> |- ! scope="row" | {{Sortname|Ivan|Leko}}, manager of [[Club Brugge KV|Club Brugge]] | [[Money laundering]] | Released without conditions<ref name="Sporza Overzicht"/> |- ! scope="row" | {{Sortname|Evert|Maeschalck|nolink=1}}, [[Sports agent|player agent]] | Private corruption ([[bribery]]) | Released without conditions<ref name="Maeschalck"/> |- ! scope="row" | {{Sortname|Olivier|Myny}}, football player for [[Oud-Heverlee Leuven|OH Leuven]], previously [[Waasland-Beveren]] | [[Criminal organisation]], private corruption ([[bribery]]) | Released without conditions<ref name="Sporza Overzicht"/> |- ! scope="row | {{Sortname|David|Van den Broeck|nolink=1}}, journalist for [[Het Nieuwsblad]] and [[Gazet van Antwerpen]] | [[Criminal organisation]], private corruption ([[bribery]]) | Released without conditions<ref name="Sporza Overzicht"/> |- |}
== Civil Parties == In Belgian criminal law, a civil party ([[:nl:Burgerlijke partij|nl]]) is a person or entity claiming to be injured by a crime, to be awarded damages following the proceedings.
As of November 2018, 3 entities have claimed to be a civil party to the investigation: the [[Royal Belgian Football Association]]<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.vrt.be/vrtnws/nl/2018/10/22/vertenten/ |title=Scheidsrechter Bart Vertenten wraakt onderzoeksrechter in voetbaldossier |date=2018-10-22 |access-date=2018-11-20 |publisher=[[Vlaamse Radio- en Televisieomroeporganisatie|VRT]] |language=Dutch}}</ref>, the Pro League<ref name="Pro League Announcement">{{Cite web |url=http://www.sport.be/nl/jupilerproleague/nieuws/article.html?Article_ID=841637 |title=Persbericht Pro League na RvB van 17 oktober |date=2018-10-17 |access-date=2018-10-17 |publisher=Pro League |language=Dutch}}</ref>, the association of all the Belgian professional football teams, and [[KFCO Beerschot Wilrijk]].<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://sporza.be/nl/2018/11/13/beerschot-wilrijk-fraudedossier-burgerlijke-partij/ |title=Beerschot Wilrijk is burgerlijke partij in fraudedossier: "Zaak van dichtbij volgen" |date=2018-11-13 |access-date=2018-11-20 |publisher=[[Sporza]] |language=Dutch}}</ref>
== Reactions == On October 11, 2018, the Pro League announced that the tenth match day for the First Division B, planned for October 13 and October 14, would be postponed.<ref name="Belgian football chaos">{{Cite news |url=https://www.vrt.be/vrtnws/en/2018/10/12/investigation-threatens-to-plunge-belgian-football-into-chaos/ |title=Investigation threatens to plunge Belgian football into chaos |date=2018-10-12 |access-date=2018-11-12 |publisher=[[Vlaamse Radio- en Televisieomroeporganisatie|VRT]]}}</ref>
Johan Verbist, arbitration coordinator for the Royal Belgian Football Association (RBFA), announced on October 11 that Bart Vertenten and Sébastien Delferière were suspended following the investigation, with the RBFA aiming to make this suspension permanent. Delferière was supposed to referee a [[UEFA Nations League|Nations League]] match on October 13, but was quickly replaced by the [[UEFA]] at the request of Verbist.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://sporza.be/nl/2018/10/11/refs-vertenten-en-delferiere-worden-geschorst/ |title=Refs Vertenten en Delferière zijn geschorst: "Klap voor imago van refs" |date=2018-10-11 |access-date=2018-10-12 |publisher=[[Sporza]] |language=Dutch}}</ref><ref name="Belgian football chaos"/>
Several politicians, including [[deputy prime minister]] [[Kris Peeters]], [[finance minister]] [[Johan Van Overtveldt]], Flemish [[sports minister]] [[Philippe Muyters]], and [[Ministry of Social Affairs|social affairs minister]] [[Maggie de Block]], announced their intentions to re-evaluate the financial benefits professional players receive following news of the scandal. Since 1978, professional sports players are taxed at a reduced RSZ ([[Social security]]) rate, designed to promote the type of employment at the time.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.hln.be/nieuws/binnenland/politiek-wil-fiscale-voordelen-voetballers-herbekijken~a00a3ea4/ |title=Politiek wil fiscale voordelen voetballers herbekijken |date=2018-10-12 |access-date=2018-10-12 |publisher=[[Het Laatste Nieuws]] |language=Dutch}}</ref>
On October 17, 2018, the Pro League announced it will set up a commission consisting of three independent experts, tasked with proposing reforms to the board of directors. This commission will consist of renowned jurist [[Melchior Wathelet]], Wouter Lambrecht, and Pierre François, CEO of the Pro League.<ref name="Pro League Announcement"/><ref name="Coucke Testifies Committee">{{Cite news |url=https://www.vrt.be/vrtnws/nl/2018/11/06/coucke-en-francois-vragen-parlement-behoud-fiscale-voordelen-van/ |title=Coucke en Francois vragen Parlement behoud fiscale voordelen van het voetbal en strengere reglementering makelaars |date=2018-11-06 |access-date=2018-11-20 |publisher=[[Vlaamse Radio- en Televisieomroeporganisatie|VRT]] |language=Dutch}}</ref>
On October 19, a week after 2 sports journalists working for [[Het Laatste Nieuws]] were charged, the newspaper announced that its top sports journalist would be taking a leave of absence, to analyze whether any deontological rule was breached. Although the journalist was not charged, he came under scrutiny because of his close ties to one of the involved player agents.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://sporza.be/nl/2018/10/19/sportjournalist-hln-non-actief/ |title=Chef voetbal Het Laatste Nieuws moet tijdelijk afstand nemen |date=2018-10-19 |access-date=2018-10-22 |publisher=[[Sporza]] |language=Dutch}}</ref>
During an interview on ''De Ochtend'', a [[Radio 1 (Belgium)|Radio 1]] programme, Sports Fraud Cell coordinator Eric Bisschop called for regulations for player agents in coordination with European directives, federal and regional laws, as well as collaboration with the RBFA, UEFA and FIFA.<ref name="Bisschop Interview"/>
On November 6, almost a month after the news of the raids broke, [[Marc Coucke]] and Pierre François, chairman and CEO of the Pro League respectively, testified before the [[Chamber of Representatives (Belgium)|Chamber of Representatives]]. During a session held by the Finances and Budget committee, Coucke defended the RSZ "[[tax shelter]]" for professional sports players. Politicians from all major Flemish parties announced intentions to revise these reductions, however Coucke mitigated this, saying the Belgian professional football industry could not afford the loss of this favorable rate and would need a different kind of subsidy.<ref name="Coucke Testifies Committee"/>
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Sports scandals]] [[Category:Football in Belgium]] [[Category:2017 scandals]] [[Category:2018 scandals]] [[Category:Corruption in Europe]] [[Category:2018 in Belgian sport]] [[Category:2017 in Belgian sport]] [[Category:Association football controversies]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Use Australian English|date=October 2013}}
In the sport of [[Australian Rules Football|Australian rules football]], the '''50-metre penalty''' is applied by umpires to a number of different infractions when a [[Free kick (Australian rules football)|free kick]] or [[Mark (Australian football)|mark]] has already been paid.
Some (particularly amateur) leagues and competitions use a 25-metre penalty. Examples of this include the [[South Australian National Football League]] (SANFL), [[Victorian Amateur Football Association]] (VAFA), [[Australian Football International Cup]] and the [[Australian Amateur Football Council]].
==Rules== When the umpire pays a 50-metre penalty, he calls time-off, measures out approximately fifty metres from the spot of the mark by running in a straight line towards the goals, and setting the new mark, unless: * the player is already within 50 metres of goal, in which case the mark becomes the exact centre of the goal line. * in the [[Australian Football League]]'s (AFL's) [[NAB Cup|preseason competition]], where a goal kicked from beyond 50m scores [[Super Goal|nine points]] instead of six, a team may choose to cut short a fifty-metre penalty at the fifty-metre line and take the higher-value, longer-range set shot.<ref>St Kilda Football CLub, [http://www.saints.com.au/tabid/5315/default.aspx?newsid=106229 2011 NAB Cup Trial Rules] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111002031759/http://www.saints.com.au/tabid/5315/default.aspx?newsid=106229 |date=2 October 2011 }}, 15 December 2010, Retrieved 5 February 2011.</ref>
Players are given a short period of time to follow the play down the field before the clock is restarted. The player cannot play on while the umpire is measuring out the 50-metre penalty, and must wait for the field umpire to blow time-on.<ref>[http://www.aflcommunityclub.com.au/fileadmin/user_upload/Umpire_AFL/Umpire_Education/Accreditation/Level_One_-_Umpires_Manual.pdf Field Umpire Accreditation Manual (Australian Football League)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110228152152/http://www.aflcommunityclub.com.au/fileadmin/user_upload/Umpire_AFL/Umpire_Education/Accreditation/Level_One_-_Umpires_Manual.pdf |date=28 February 2011 }}</ref>
Infractions which can result in a 50-metre penalty include: * Arguing with, disputing the decision of, or using abusive language towards an umpire. * ''Scragging'' the player who has taken a mark; that is, to tackle the player or impede him from taking the kick as quickly as he would like. This rule has been applied more stringently since 2006 to give defensive players less time to [[Flooding (Australian football)|flood]] the defence, and to keep the game more flowing. * Failing to return the ball quickly and on the full to a player who has been awarded a free kick. * Wasting time, deliberately or inadvertently, by kicking the ball forward after one's team has conceded a free kick. * Using unnecessary roughness against a player who has already taken a mark. * ''Running over the mark''; the man standing on the mark cannot move forward, and must respond if called to recede by the umpire. * ''Running through the mark''; other defensive players who are not standing on the mark may not run across the imaginary line between the man standing the mark and the man taking the kick, unless following his direct opponent. * ''Entering the protected zone''; defensive players may not impede an opponent by entering or remaining within the corridor of space extending ten metres either side of the imaginary line between the man standing the mark and the man taking the kick, and extending backwards, unless following his direct opponent. * If any free kick is paid against the defensive team while a mark or free kick is to be taken, the umpire either pays the free kick to the violated player at the spot of the foul, or awards a 50-metre penalty to the player with the ball, depending upon which penalty brings the attacking team closer to goal. * Any free kick resulting from an [[Interchange (Australian rules football)|interchange]] infringement or a line-up has an additional 50-metre penalty applied to it; these are the only circumstances under which a 50-metre penalty is automatically applied to a free kick without further infringement.
==History== The fifteen-yard penalty was first introduced at senior level by the [[Victorian Football Association]] in 1939, as one of the rules included in its [[throw-pass era|rival code]] of Australian rules football. The rule was introduced to give the umpire a means of penalising a player who cribbed over the mark or wasted time on the mark;<ref name="15yards">{{cite news|newspaper=Advocate|publication-place=Burnie, TAS|title=Interpretations of rules|page=9|date=5 August 1939}}</ref> under standard rules at the time, such infractions could only be policed by reports.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Daily News|publication-place=Perth, WA|page=14|date=4 May 1939|title=Cribbing on the mark}}</ref> The [[Australian National Football Council]] introduced the rule into the national rules during 1954 (leagues began using it in 1955), which was applied to both time-wasting and to crude, late challenges on the player with the mark.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The News|publication-place=Adelaide, SA|page=32|date=13 July 1954|title=Fos Williams on 15-yard penalty clause}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Sun News-Pictorial|author=Kevin Hogan|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC|date=7 April 1955|page=33|title="Get tough" order given umpires on new rule}}</ref> The length was increased to 50 metres in [[1988 VFL season|1988]] when it was determined that the fifteen metre penalty had become insufficient to deter time-wasting and scragging.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Sun News-Pictorial|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC|author=Daryl Timms|page=84|date=16 March 1988|title='Go' on footy rules}}</ref>
==Rationale== Fifty metres is the average length of a long kick. As 50-metre penalties are awarded only to players who have already taken a mark or been awarded a free kick, the penalty is the equivalent of having made a long pass downfield (with the playing area being over 150m long). This interpretation allows the fifty metre length to be adjusted to appropriate values for lower age groups.
With the exception of interchange infringements, a player must already have a free kick or a mark to receive a 50-metre penalty. Often, crowds will call for "fifty!" when they see a player hurt behind play or in a marking contest. However, many fans are unaware that unless the mark is taken, fifty metres can never be awarded. There was an exception to this rule made in [[2000 AFL season|2000]], when a 50-metre penalty would automatically be awarded against any player who was reported for a non-wrestling offence; so unpopular was the change that it was repealed after seventeen rounds.
==Notable 50-metre penalties==
*The most famous 15-metre penalty occurred in the [[1987 VFL season|1987 preliminary final]], in an incident where [[Melbourne Football Club|Melbourne]]'s [[Jim Stynes]] ran across the mark against [[Hawthorn Football Club|Hawthorn]]. [[Gary Buckenara]], needing a 55-metre goal [[After the siren kicks in Australian rules football|after the final siren]] for Hawthorn to steal the victory, was brought 15 metres closer to goal. Buckenara converted the goal, Hawthorn advanced to the [[1987 VFL Grand Final|Grand Final]], and Melbourne's long [[Curse of Norm Smith|premiership drought]] continued.<ref>[https://archive.is/20130702082819/http://www.thestar.ie/star/afl-rule-is-well-worth-trying-here/ AFL rule is well worth trying here | Irish Daily Star]</ref> *In [[2005 AFL season|2005]] an incident where [[Essendon Football Club|Essendon]]'s [[Mark Johnson (footballer)|Mark Johnson]] called an opposition player from [[Sydney Swans|Sydney]] a "weak dog" when he wouldn't get up and was playing for a free kick was rewarded with a 50-metre penalty to the Sydney player. It was also believed Johnson engaged in abusive language with the umpire which may have influenced the decision.<ref>[http://www.redandwhiteonline.com/forum/showthread.php/9092-AFL-Response-to-MJ-Fifty AFL Response to MJ Fifty]</ref> *During the infamous [[AFL siren controversy|St Kilda vs Fremantle "Sirengate" match]] in round 5, [[2006 AFL season|2006]], [[St Kilda Football Club|St Kilda]] full-forward [[Fraser Gehrig]] abused and argued with the umpire, gave up five consecutive free kicks: a free kick in defensive goal square, three consecutive 50-metre penalties (spanning the entire length of the field, yielding a certain goal to Fremantle) and an additional free kick to Fremantle after the goal.<ref>[http://www.dockerland.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=254:qdockers-saints-and-sirengateq&catid=8&Itemid=103 "~Dockers, Saints and Sirengate~"]</ref> *In Round 1, [[2007 AFL season|2007]], umpire [[Stuart Wenn]] awarded a short fifty-metre penalty against [[Collingwood Football Club|Collingwood's]] [[Heath Shaw]] after a mark by the [[North Melbourne Football Club|Kangaroos]]' [[Shannon Grant]] with three minutes remaining on the game. Wenn positioned Shaw approximately on the kick-off line when he should have been on the goal line. Grant missed the 15-metre set shot, and the Kangaroos lost the game by three points.<ref>[http://www.news.com.au/breaking-news/laidley-fumes-at-umpire-blunder/story-e6frfkp9-1111113262221 Laidley fumes at umpire blunder | News.com.au]</ref> *In Round 11, [[2009 AFL season|2009]], triple 50-metre penalties occurred when [[Sydney Swans]]' [[Barry Hall]] put his arm around the neck of [[Hawthorn Football Club|Hawthorn]]'s [[Jarryd Roughead]], who ended up in his own goal square. Hall was benched beside his coach, and Sydney lost by just 11 points.<ref>[http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/barry-hall-brain-explosion-gifts-hawks-game/story-e6frf7jo-1225728808644 Barry Hall brain explosion gifts Hawks game | Herald Sun]</ref> *In [[2017 AFL season#Round 15|Round 15, 2017]], late in the match between {{AFL Fre}} and {{AFL StK}} at [[Subiaco Oval|Domain Stadium]], St Kilda forward [[Tim Membrey]] took a mark inside 50, then teammate [[Nick Riewoldt]] asked for the ball back from Fremantle's [[Griffin Logue]], fooling the latter into thinking that it was Riewoldt who took the mark. Logue gave away a 50-metre penalty for time-wasting, then Membrey kicked the goal to give the Saints a nine-point win.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.triplem.com.au/sport/afl/news/heartbreaking-player-profile-shows-nick-riewoldt-stitched-up-one-of-his-biggest-fans|title=Heartbreaking Player Profile Shows Nick Riewoldt Stitched Up One Of His Biggest Fans|publisher=Triple M|date=3 July 2017|accessdate=3 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/sport/afl/teams/st-kilda/footy-fans-furious-after-nick-riewoldt-tricks-fremantle/news-story/280329e5b6f6fd93a28f9a84a59410e6|title=Footy fans furious after Nick Riewoldt tricks Fremantle|publisher=Herald Sun|date=2 July 2017|accessdate=3 July 2017}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Laws of Australian rules football]] * [[Penalty (rugby union)]]: a similar rule exists in rugby union, where the mark is moved forward 10 metres if the defending team do not retreat sufficiently far after a tapped penalty or free kick, or if dissent is shown to the referee.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Australian rules football terminology}}
[[Category:Australian rules football terminology]] [[Category:Laws of Australian rules football]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2015}} {{Expand French|Adriana Karembeu|date=June 2016}} {{Infobox model | name = Adriana Karembeu | image = Adriana Sklenarikova Karembeu 2006 - 2.jpg| imagesize =
| birth_name = Adriana Sklenaříková | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1971|9|17}}<ref name="FMD profile" /> | birth_place = [[Brezno]], Czechoslovakia (now Slovakia)<ref name="FMD profile" /> | death_date = | death_place = | height = {{convert|1.78|m|ftin|abbr=on}}<ref name="FMD profile" /> | haircolor = Blonde<ref name="FMD profile" /> | eyecolor = Blue<ref name="FMD profile" /> | agency = | alias = | spouse = {{ubl|{{marriage|[[Christian Karembeu]]|1998|2012}}|{{marriage|Aram Ohanian|2014}}}} | partner = [[Mick Hucknall]] (1994–1997) | website = }}
'''Adriana Sklenaříková''' (born 17 September 1971) is a Slovak fashion model and actress.<ref name="FMD profile"/> She is a former [[Guinness World Records|Guinness record]] holder for the longest legs among female models (at almost 1.24 m).<ref name="FMD profile"/>
==Early life== Karembeu was born in [[Brezno]], a town in central Slovakia.<ref name="FMD profile"/>
==Career== [[File:Adriana Sklenarikova Karembeu 2006.jpg|thumb|Karembeu at the [[2006 Cannes Film Festival|2006]] [[Cannes Film Festival]]]]
While studying medicine in Prague,<ref name="FMD profile" /> Karembeu entered and won a modelling contest.<ref name="FMD profile"/>
In 1998, she was hired as one of the models for the [[Wonderbra]] campaign.<ref name="BBC News August 1998"/>
In the United States, she modeled for [[Victoria's Secret]].<ref name="FMD profile"/>
In 2005 she featured in the Channel 5 TV documentary [https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2170319/?ref_=nv_sr_2 Bra Wars: Boom or Bust]
In 2008 she participated in ''[[Rendez-vous en terre inconnue]]'' on [[France 2]].
In 2011 she was a contestant in the first season of the French ''[[Danse avec les stars (France season 1)|Dancing with the Stars]]''.<ref name="7sur7 January 2011"/>
==Filmography== {| class="wikitable" ! Year ! Title ! Role ! Director ! Notes |- | rowspan=1|1999 | ''[[Domenica In]]'' | Herself | Cesare Gigli | |- | rowspan=2|2004 | ''[[Jak básníci neztrácejí naději]]'' | Madame Krásná | Dusan Klein | |- | ''3 petites filles'' | Laetitia | [[Jean-Loup Hubert]] | |- | rowspan=1|2007 | ''Adriana et moi'' | Adriana | Williams Crépin | TV Movie |- | rowspan=1|2008 | ''[[Asterix at the Olympic Games (film)|Asterix at the Olympic Games]]'' | [[List of Asterix characters#Mrs. Geriatrix|Mrs Geriatrix]] | [[Frédéric Forestier]] & [[Thomas Langmann]] | |- | rowspan=2|2013 | ''[[R.I.S, police scientifique]]'' | Krystel Regnier | Claire de la Rochefoucauld | TV Series (1 Episode) |- | ''[[Scènes de ménage (TV Series)|Scènes de ménage]]'' | Vanessa | Karim Adda & Francis Duquet | TV Series (2 Episodes) |- | rowspan=1|2014 | ''Nos chers voisins'' | Jennifer | Emmanuel Rigaut | TV Series (1 Episode) |- | rowspan=5|2015 | ''[[Murders at#Episode 3 : Murders at Étretat|Meurtres à Étretat]]'' | Karine Zenko | Laurence Katrian | TV Movie |- | ''Enfin en vacances, à la mer'' | Vanessa | Karim Adda & Francis Duquet (2) | TV Movie |- | ''Section de recherches'' | Tina Kepler | [[Gérard Marx]] | TV Series (1 Episode) |- | ''Doc Martin'' | Adriana Soupov | Stéphane Kappes | TV Series (1 Episode) |- | ''Ex-Model'' | Adriana | Emmanuel Sapolsky | TV Series (1 Episode) |}
== Others == She was one of the contestants during the [[Danse avec les stars (France season 1)|first season]] of ''[[Danse avec les stars]]''.
==Personal life==
Karembeu had previously dated English singer [[Mick Hucknall]] from 1994 to 1997.
She met French football player [[Christian Karembeu]] on a flight from Paris to Milan in 1998, and they were married in December that year.<ref name="FMD profile" /> On 9 March 2011, in an interview to French magazine ''[[Paris Match]]'', Adriana revealed that she was separating from her husband.<ref name="Paris Match March 2011" /> She stated that the causes for the separation were the couple's constant exposure in the media and their "hectic lifestyle" as well as him being "upset to see photographs of [her] with other men appearing in the press and speculation that [she] had a lover".<ref name="France Today March 2011" /> Christian refused questions from the media about the divorce, stating that he would not comment in public about his private life.<ref name="Francesoir March 2011"/>
In June 2014, she married [[Armenians|Armenian]] businessman Aram Ohanian, her boyfriend of three years. Their wedding was held in Marrakesh, Morocco, and was attended by numerous film and show business stars.<ref>{{cite web|title=Adriana Karembeu va se marier|url=http://www.leparisien.fr/laparisienne/actu-people/adriana-karembeu-va-se-marier-02-06-2014-3890307.php|publisher=[[Le Parisien]]|date=2 June 2014|accessdate=8 June 2014|language=French}}</ref>
==Award== *2009 [[Vienna Fashion Award]], category ''Style Icon''
==References== {{reflist|refs= <ref name="FMD profile">{{cite web |title=Adriana Sklenarikova Karembeu Profile |url=http://www.fashionmodeldirectory.com/models/Adriana_Sklenarikova+Karembeu |work=The Fashion Model Directory (FMD) |accessdate=7 September 2010}}</ref> <ref name="Paris Match March 2011">{{cite web |title=Exclusif. Adriana annonce sa séparation à Paris Match (Adriana announces her separation in Paris Match) |url=http://www.parismatch.com/People-Match/Mode/Actu/Exclusif-Adriana-Christian-Karembeu-separation-259437/ |publisher=ParisMatch.com |date=9 March 2011 |accessdate=20 August 2012|language=fr}}</ref> <ref name="France Today March 2011">{{cite web |title=Adriana and Christian Karembeu separate |url=http://www.france-today.com/2011/03/adriana-and-christian-karembeu-separate.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110619220316/http://www.france-today.com/2011/03/adriana-and-christian-karembeu-separate.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=19 June 2011 |publisher=France Today |date=10 March 2011 |accessdate=20 August 2012 }}</ref> <ref name="Francesoir March 2011">{{cite web |title=Adriana quitte Christian Karembeu (Adriana leaves Christian Karembeu)|url=http://www.francesoir.fr/people-tv/people/adriana-quitte-christian-karembeu-80347.html |publisher=France Soir |date=9 March 2011 |accessdate=20 August 2012|language=fr}}</ref> <ref name="BBC News August 1998">{{cite news |title='Wonderbras are safe' says Adriana |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/health/149929.stm |publisher=BBC News |date=12 August 1998 |accessdate=20 August 2012}}</ref> <ref name="7sur7 January 2011">{{cite web |title=Bigard, Manoukian et Karembeu dans "Danse avec les stars" |url=http://www.7sur7.be/7s7/fr/1540/Television/article/detail/1213614/2011/01/26/Bigard-Manoukian-et-Karembeu-dans-Danse-avec-les-stars.dhtml |publisher=7sur7.be |author=Editorial |date=26 January 2011 |accessdate=18 March 2013|language=fr}}</ref> }}
==External links== {{Commons category|Adriana Karembeu}} *{{Fashionmodel}} *{{IMDb name|id=1141714|name=Adriana Karembeu}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20161112025626/http://www.askmen.com/celebs/women/models/22_adriana_sklenarikova.html Adriana Sklenarikova – AskMen.com] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20131111084636/http://stars.likeat.me/board/24/ Adriana Karembeu – likeat.me] {{Danse Avec Les Stars 2011}}
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
In [[association football]], [[rugby league]], [[rugby union]] and [[Australian rules football]], a '''dummy''' or '''feint''' is a player deceiving the opposition into believing he is going to pass, shoot, move in a certain direction, or receive the ball and instead doing something entirely different, thus gaining an advantage.
==Association football== In association football, a dummy (feint) is often used when [[dribbling]], in offensive situations. Examples used in order to deceive an opponent into what direction you will move, include: the [[step over]] as used by [[Ronaldo (Brazilian footballer)|Ronaldo]] and [[Cristiano Ronaldo]], the [[Flip flap (association football)|flip flap]] (also known as "elastico") used by [[Ronaldinho]], [[Lionel Messi]] and [[Ronaldo (Brazilian footballer)|Ronaldo]], the [[Marseille turn]] (also known as the "360" or "roulette") used by [[Zinedine Zidane]], the [[Rainbow kick|rainbow flick]] as used by [[Neymar]], the [[Cruijff Turn|Cruyff Turn]] named after [[Johan Cruyff]], and dragging the ball around a defender without it leaving your foot as used by [[Romário]].<ref>[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2011/writers/sid_lowe/02/18/ronaldo.retirement/ "Ronaldo was simply a phenomenon"]. Sports Illustrated. Retrieved June 2, 2014</ref><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2014/jun/11/world-cup-stunning-moments-johan-cruyff-turn-1974 "World Cup: 25 stunning moments … No25: the Cruyff Turn is born in 1974"]. The Guardian. Retrieved June 11, 2014</ref><ref>David Goldblatt (2009). "The Football Book". p. 129. D Kindersley Ltd</ref><ref>Lowe, Sid (2013). "Fear and Loathing in La Liga: The True Story of Barcelona and Real Madrid". p. 288. Random House</ref>
The next most common instance is also an offensive situation, in which a player, in a reasonable shooting area, fakes a shot to trick a defender coming in for a tackle and have him flinch away. This allows the player to go around the defender and shoot from a closer distance. This dummy can also be used on a goalkeeper in a one-on-one situation: a notable example being [[Goal of the Century|The Goal of the Century]] scored by [[Diego Maradona]] where, having run half the length of the field past several outfield players, he faced goalkeeper Peter Shilton and left him on his backside with a feint, before slotting the ball into the net.<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/world-cup/6700645/Top-10-World-Cup-goals.html?mobile=basic "Top 10 World Cup goals"]. The Telegraph. Retrieved August 19, 2014</ref>
There is another situation that is used often enough that "dummy" becomes a verb. In this scenario, a player goes toward the path of passing ball, pretends to trap it and lets it goes through the legs. This is to allow his team mate—who is also moving toward the ball but further away—can retrieve it. Another common scenario is the "dummying" player running after the ball after letting it go through the legs. This is very effective if the trap fake is convincing because the stop/start on the defending player is always slower than the attacking player who has the momentum.
==Rugby league and rugby union== In rugby league football and rugby union football, a dummy has a similar meaning, but is generally confined to a player leading their opposing players into believing that they are about to pass or sometimes kick the ball, but instead retaining and running with the ball. This has the effect of drawing defending players to the apparent recipient of the dummy pass. One of the first rugby players to be credited with using the dummy, or at least taking the technique to New Zealand, was [[Tommy Haslam]]. Haslam played for [[Batley Bulldogs|Batley]] before the rugby schism and was a member of the 1888 [[British and Irish Lions|British Isles]] tour of [[1888 British Lions tour to New Zealand and Australia|New Zealand and Australia]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Griffiths |first=John|coauthors= |title=British Lions |year=1990 |publisher=Crowood Press|page=14 |location=Swindon |isbn=1-85223-541-1}}</ref>
==Australian rules football== In Australian rules football the term 'dummy' again has a similar meaning to other football codes. A dummy is used to evade a tackler by feigning a hand pass or foot pass to a teammate and then changing direction suddenly to escape the opponent who has been fooled by the move.
==See also== {{portal|Sports}} *[[Pelé runaround move]] *[[Nutmeg (football)|Nutmeg]] *[[Rabona]] *[[Rainbow kick]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Dummy (Football)}} [[Category:Association football terminology]] [[Category:Australian rules football terminology]] [[Category:Rugby league terminology]] [[Category:Rugby union terminology]]

It currently plays in the [[Djibouti Premier League]].https://int.soccerway.com/teams/djibouti/gendarmerie-nationale/20851/matches/ ==Stadium== Currently the team plays at the 40000 capacity [[Stade du Ville]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://int.soccerway.com/teams/djibouti/gendarmerie-nationale/20851/ Soccerway] [[Category:Football clubs in Djibouti]] {{Djibouti-sport-stub}}

revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''Gossaum''''' ({{korean|hangul=고싸움}}) is a traditional [[Sport in South Korea|Korean sport]] played in Chilseok village, [[Nam District, Gwangju|Nam-gu]] as part of the [[Korean New Year|New Year's celebrations]]. It is designated an [[Important Intangible Cultural Properties of Korea|Important Intangible Cultural Property]].<ref name="Kwalliguk2001">{{cite book|author=Korea (South). Munhwajae Kwalliguk|title=Korean Intangible Cultural Properties: . Folk dramas, games, and rites|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_ggaAQAAIAAJ|accessdate=26 March 2013|year=2001|publisher=Hollym International Corporation|isbn=978-1-56591-164-2|page=74}}</ref> It is played by two teams, each of which carries a Go, a large, braided straw structure. The objective is for one team to drive the other's Go to the ground.<ref name="mycong">{{cite web|title=Folk Village Ritual and Play, Gossaumnori |last=Seung-hyi |first=Rhy |work=Chonnam Tribune |publisher=CNU |accessdate=26 March 2013 |date=10 March 2008 |url=http://www.mycong.com/news/quickViewArticleView.html?idxno=5194 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130419110324/http://www.mycong.com/news/quickViewArticleView.html?idxno=5194 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=19 April 2013 }}</ref> The name is derived from "go" ("loop", literally, the looped knot of a coat string) and "sseum" ("fight").<ref name="Kongbogwan2003">{{cite book|author=Korea (South). Haeoe Kongbogwan|title=Handbook of Korea|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IBpxAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=26 March 2013|year=2003|publisher=Korean Overseas Information Service|isbn=978-89-7375-005-4|page=630}}</ref> In 2002 the game was commemorated on a postage stamp.<ref>{{cite web|title=WNS:KR057.02|publisher=Universal Postal Union|url=http://www.wnsstamps.ch/en/stamps/KR057.02|accessdate=26 March 2013}}</ref>
==Setup== ===Go=== Each Go is around 15m long, and consists of a large straw loop at the end of a long, thick cylinder, supported on poles. Two "tails", at the opposite end of the structure from the loop, serve to provide a rudimentary steering mechanism. During play, the two Go are lifted above head height by the teams, and the loops are brought into contact and pushed against one another. Due to the ritual nature of the contest, one team's Go is larger than the other, making the contest somewhat one-sided.<ref name="mycong"/>
===Teams=== The teams are designated ''Dongbu'' ("East") and ''Seobu'' ("West"), and wear blue and red respectively. Each team consists of around 70-80 people; including the ''Julpaejang'' or leader, who sits astride the Go and directs his team; the ''Gomen-saram'' or carriers, who lift the Go; and the ''Kkorijul-jabi'' or tail-holders (predominantly women) who steer the Go using its two tails. Each team also has a number of standby players who sing and shout chants of encouragement to the players.<ref name="mycong"/>
==Gameplay== At the command of the ''julpaejang'' the teams rush forward and ram the loops of their two Go against one another, attempting to drive the opposing team back or push its Go to the ground. If, after pushing, neither Go is dislodged, one of the ''julpaejang'' will give the order to retreat and the two Gos will separate before repeating the process. During such separations, the ''gomen-saram'' will raise and lower the Go to demonstrate their fighting spirit.
When one Go has been brought down four times, the game is over.<ref name="mycong"/><ref name="Hanʼguk Munhwa">{{cite book|title=Hanʼguk Munhwa|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GycOAQAAMAAJ|accessdate=26 March 2013|year=1984|publisher=Korean Cultural Service|volume=5|page=19}}</ref>
==Gossaumnori== ''Gossaum'' plays the central role in the ''Gossaumnori'' festival. Other aspects of this [[fertility rite]] include prayers to the spirits of the local mountains and forests, exorcism rite, and traditional music and dancing. Because the Western side of the village is thought to represent [[fecundity]], the ''Seobu'' Go is larger than the ''Dongbu'' one, since only if ''Seobu'' win will the villager's prayers for a prosperous year be granted. Historically, in the event that no clear winner emerged, the Go would be dismantled and their straw ropes used in a [[Juldarigi|tug-of-war contest]] instead.<ref name="mycong"/><ref name="Kwalliguk2001"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Traditional sports]] [[Category:Sport in Korea]] [[Category:Important Intangible Cultural Properties of South Korea]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Use British English|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox venue | name = Hackney Wick Stadium | nickname = | image = | location = [[London Borough of Hackney|Hackney]], [[London]] | coordinates = | opened = 1932 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = 1997 | owner = | operator = | surface = }}
'''Hackney Wick Stadium''' was a sports stadium located at Waterden Road in the [[London Borough of Hackney]]
==Origins== The site chose for the stadium was on land known as Hackney Marshes west of the River Lea and on the west side of the Waterden Road.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.old-maps.co.uk/#/Map/537346/184983/13/101329|title=OS Plan 1948-1949|publisher=old-maps.co.uk}}</ref> The stadium was constructed from September 1931 until 1932 and cost £70,000 to build and after completion £18,000 in wages had been paid to the builders.<ref name=HW>{{cite news|title=Hackney's New Dog Racing Track, April 1932|year=1932|newspaper=Hendon and Finchley Times}}</ref>
==Opening== Hackney opened On Friday 8 April 1932 under the affiliation of the British Greyhound Tracks Control Society (BGTCS) the rival to the larger [[National Greyhound Racing Club]]. Thirteen thousand people attended the first night and witnessed [[Marjorie Graves]], MP for South Hackney officially open the track. The capacity of the track was put between 30,000-50,000 and a [[Tote board|totalisator]] had been installed for the first night. A greyhound called Bullseye became the first ever winner at the track. Although the meeting was advertised as the first official meeting there had been a dress rehearsal two days previous on Wednesday 6 April which attracted 12,000 people.<ref name=HW/>
The company responsible for the project was Hackney Wick Stadium Ltd headed by Managing Director Arthur Gilbert and Racing Manager Fred Whitehead with William Chandler also holding shares in the new company, Chandler would in due course buy the [[Walthamstow Stadium|Crooked Billet]] independent track and turn it into [[Walthamstow Stadium]] one year later.<ref name=PHT>{{cite book|last=Tarter|first=P Howard|title=Greyhound Racing Encyclopedia|year=1949|publisher=Fleet Publishing Company Ltd}}</ref>
==Greyhound history== After [[World War II]] [[Hendon Greyhound Stadium]] and Hackney Wick merged to become the Hackney and Hendon Greyhounds Ltd company. The resident kennels featured six ranges with each able to house up to fifty greyhounds, paddocks sat next to each range with cooking facilities and a veterinary surgeon on site. The kennel fees were 17s 6d for each greyhound.<ref name=PHT/>
In the early 1950s Mr S Pay became the Racing Manager after Fred Whitehead was promoted to Director of Racing for both Hackney and Hendon. Pay was later replaced by Hendon Racing Manager D G Lewis before Michael Marksbecame Racing Manager for three decades until the day the stadium closed. The stadium offered eight buffet and licensed bars during racing held on Thursday and Saturday nights at 7.45pm. The circuit had a circumference of 472 yards and the greyhounds raced behind an 'Outside Sumner' hare system. Trainers in the 1960s included Annetts, Reg Bosley, Brown, Colebrooke, Cox, Paddy Gordon, Hedley and Lionel Maxen.<ref>{{cite book|last=Genders|first=Roy|title=The Greyhound and Racing Greyhound|page =116|year=1975|publisher=Page Brothers (Norwich)|isbn=0-85020-0474}}</ref>
In the 1970s Mr G.Crookbank the tracks chief electrician had invented photoelectric timing gear that would revolutionise the sport. Hand timing would become a thing of the past after Crookbank came up with the idea that a greyhound’s race time could be recorded electronically. The invention known as 'Automatic Ray Timing' would remain as the timing method until the advent of modern computer timing. The Hackney sales became a major feature of business throughout the year, these sales became a prominent way for buying and selling greyhounds in London.<ref name=RG>{{cite book|last=Genders|first=Roy|title=The Encyclopedia of Greyhound Racing|year=1981|publisher=Pelham Books Ltd|isbn=07207-1106-1}}</ref>
In 1969 [[Park Royal Stadium]] and [[New Cross Stadium]] both closed resulting in the Bookmakers Afternoon Greyhound Service (BAGS) being switched to Hendon and Hackney, the racing image of Hackney would change forever as it became the number one BAGS track. Afternoon meetings were introduced and eventually there would be no evening meetings at the track with the Saturday matinee BAGS replacing the Saturday night.<ref name=RG/>
In 1970 businessman [[George Alfred Walker|George Walker]], brother of boxing champion [[Billy Walker (boxer)|Billy Walker]] arranged a reverse takeover of Hackney and Hendon Greyhounds Stadium Ltd. This meant his private company bought a public company and the new merger resulted in a new company called [[Brent Walker]]. This resulted in the end for the Hendon Greyhound Stadium because it was sold to make way for the UK’s first stand-alone shopping centre on the site that would soon be known as the Brent Cross shopping centre.<ref name=RG/>
It was not until the closure of sister track Hendon that Hackney Wick hosted a competition of note. The Guineas long associated with Park Royal had switched to Hendon in 1969 which in turn now found its way to Hackney. Three years later 'The Lead' was introduced and would also become a valuable addition to the calendar.<ref name=RG/> In 1976 local hound Westmead Champ trained by Pam Heasman reached the final of the [[English Greyhound Derby]] and was voted [[Greyhound of the Year Awards|Greyhound of the Year]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Dack|first=Barrie|title=Greyhound Derby, the first 60 years|year=1990|publisher=Ringpress Books|isbn=0-948955-36-8}}</ref>
Hackney fell out with the NGRC in 1987 when the governing body announced that they would charge £300 to a track staging a BAGS meeting covered by [[Satellite Information Services]] (S.I.S) plus ten percent of the tracks BAGS fees. Hackney refused and [[Ladbrokes]] took legal advice over the situation but all BAGS tracks would eventually pay a fee to the NGRC. Another race called the Lincoln was hosted by Hackney from 1986 and in 1988 Minnies Siren trained by Terry Duggan won the [[TV Trophy (greyhounds)|BBC Television Trophy]]. Brent Walker bought [[William Hill (bookmaker)|William Hill/Mecca]] from [[Grand Metropolitan]] in 1989 and one year later leading trainer John 'Ginger' McGee Sr. joined the track.<ref>{{cite book|last=Genders|first=Roy|title=NGRC book of Greyhound Racing|pages =29–44|year=1990|publisher=Pelham Books Ltd|isbn=0-7207-1804-X}}</ref>
==Renovation and closure== During 1991 it transpired that Brent Walker had amassed debts of £1.2 billion, George Walker was removed from the board and the banker took control of the company’s assets. With the bank controlling matters there were numerous rumours about the future of the track. By 1994 the stadium had been acquired by a company called London Stadium Hackney Ltd who were in turn owned by Fleetfoot Racing formed in 1992. Work began on an ambitious project including a £12 million restaurant and state of the art facilities, leading trainers were recruited and the stadium was rebranded 'The London Stadium'.<ref>{{cite book|last=Fry|first=Paul|title=The Official NGRC Greyhound Racing Yearbook|pages =205–208|year=1995|publisher=Ringpress Books|isbn=186054-010-4}}</ref>
At the end of 1994 ex-[[Lloyds Bank|Lloyds]] broker and racing journalist Robert Parker left the company as its director to be replaced by Stephen Rea. Beset with construction problems and internal disagreements the original £14 million scheme to develop the neglected stadium had run into serious problems. Extra cash was raised by rights issues with companies including Rothschild, Henderson Venture Managers and Samuel Montagu. In October 1995 the new stadium was finally ready offering first-class facilities and significantly high prize money. However on the reopening night and despite a capacity crowd the stadium went into receivership the same evening. Investigations began and Parker was pursued by Roger Cook on ITV’s television program ''[[The Cook Report]]''. Fleetfoot Racing Ltd had lasted just three years and the stadium was closed on 4 January 1997.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://betting.betfair.com/greyhound-racing/lost-tracks/bankrupt-on-the-first-night-th-311007.html|title=Bankrupt on the first night - the desperate story of the 'new' Hackney Wick|publisher=Betfair}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://hackneyreunion.com/A-Tale-of-Two-Stadiums-|title=A Tale of Two Stadiums|publisher=Hackney reunion.com}}</ref>
The stadium was left derelict for several years until it was bought by the [[London Development Agency]] and demolished in 2003. The site was the location of the [[London Olympics Media Centre]], the main media and broadcasting centre for the [[2012 Summer Olympics]] and the [[2012 Summer Paralympics]].
== Speedway history == [[Hackney Wick Wolves]] speedway team raced there before [[World War II]] . The [[Hackney Hawks]] speedway team rode at the venue from 1963 to 1983. [[Hackney Kestrels]] speedway team rode here from 1984 until 1990. In 1996, a speedway team under the name of [[London Lions (speedway)|London Lions]] rode but it was found to be financially unviable.<ref>Fenn, C.(2003). ''Hackney Speedway, Friday at Eight''. {{ISBN|0-7524-2737-7}}</ref>
The [[Speedway Grand Prix of Great Britain|British Speedway Grand Prix]] was held at the stadium in 1995 and 1996.<ref>Bamford, R. & Shailes, G. (2002). ''A History of the World Speedway Championship''. Stroud: Tempus Publishing. {{ISBN|0-7524-2402-5}}</ref>
The speedway track was {{convert|345|yd|m|abbr=off}} in length.
==See also== *[[Speedway Grand Prix of Great Britain]]
==External links== *[http://www.hackneyhawks.co.uk// Hackney Hawks Website] *[http://i73.photobucket.com/albums/i204/hammer1980/hackneystadium1938.jpg Aerial view of Hackney Wick Stadium 1938] *[http://www.runtrackdir.com UK Running Track Directory] ''Details of the history of the track'' *[http://betting.betfair.com/greyhound-racing/general/the-wick-was-ramshackle-basic-241007.html The Wick was ramshackle, basic beast of a greyhound track ... and all the better for it] Article on Betfair.com *[http://betting.betfair.com/greyhound-racing/lost-tracks/bankrupt-on-the-first-night-th-311007.html Bankrupt on the first night - the desperate story of the 'new' Hackney Wick] Article on Betfair.com *[http://betting.betfair.com/greyhound-racing/lost-tracks/regeneration-came-five-years-t-061107.html Regeneration came five years too late for much-loved Hackney Wick] Article on Betfair.com
