revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/2001:8003:34CE:7200:85E6:26DB:810F:A85D|2001:8003:34CE:7200:85E6:26DB:810F:A85D]] ([[User talk:2001:8003:34CE:7200:85E6:26DB:810F:A85D|talk]]) to last version by GreenC bot
revision.text:
The '''history of [[orienteering]]''' begins in the late 19th century in [[Sweden]], where it originated as [[military training]]. The actual term "orienteering" was first used in 1886 at the Swedish [[Military Academy Karlberg]] and meant the crossing of unknown land with the aid of a map and a compass. The competitive sport began when the first competition was held for Swedish military officers on 28 May 1893 at the yearly games of the [[Stockholm]] garrison.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.orientering.se/Historia-och-statistik/Milstolpar-i-utvecklingen|title=Historiska milstolpar|publisher=Svenska Orienteringsförbundet|language=Swedish|accessdate=2009-10-26}}</ref> The first civilian competition, in [[Norway]] on 31 October 1897, was sponsored by the Tjalve Sports Club and held near [[Oslo]]. The course was long by modern standards, at 19.5 km, on which only three controls were placed. The competition was won by Peder Fossum in a time of 1 hour, 47 minutes, and 7 seconds.<ref name=palmer_18>{{cite book|last=Palmer|first=Peter|title=The Complete Orienteering Manual|publisher=The Crowood Press Ltd.|year=1997|edition=1|volume=1|pages=18–19|isbn=1-86126-095-4}}</ref>
==Europe between the two world wars== {{see also|Land navigation (military)}} At the end of [[World War I]] the first large scale orienteering meet was organized in 1918 by Major [[Ernst Killander]] of Stockholm, Sweden. Then President of the Stockholm Amateur Athletic Association, [[Ernst Killander|Killander]] was a [[Scouting Movement]]<!-- leave redirect; destination page may need to be split --> leader who saw orienteering as an opportunity to interest youth in athletics. The meet was held south of Stockholm in 1919 and was attended by 220 athletes.<ref name="palmer_18"/><ref name=boga_1>{{cite book |last=Boga|first=Steven|title=Orienteering: The Sport of Navigating with Map & Compass |publisher=Stackpole Books|location=Mechanicsburg, Pennsylvania, USA|year=1997 |edition=1|volume=1|pages=1|chapter=1|isbn=0-8117-2870-6}}</ref> Killander is credited with coining the [[Swedish language|Swedish]] word ''orientering'', from which the word orienteering is derived, in publicity materials for this meet.<ref name=orientering>{{cite book |last=Palmer|first=Peter|title=The Complete Orienteering Manual|publisher=The Crowood Press Ltd. |year=1997 |edition=1 |volume=1 |pages=19 |isbn=1-86126-095-4 }}</ref> [[Ernst Killander|Killander]] continued to develop the rules and principles of the sport, and today is widely regarded throughout Scandinavia as the "Father of Orienteering".
[[Image:Baseplatecompass.jpg|thumb|left|[[Protractor compass]], first introduced in Sweden in 1933.]] The sport gained popularity with the development of more reliable compasses in the 1930s. The first international competition between orienteers of Sweden and Norway was held outside Oslo, Norway, in 1932. In 1933, the Swedish compass manufacturer [[Silva compass|Silva Sweden AB]] introduced a new compass design, the [[protractor compass]]. Until the introduction of the [[thumb compass]], the protractor compass would remain the state of the art in the sport. By 1934, over a quarter million Swedes were actively participating in the sport, and orienteering had spread to [[Finland]], [[Switzerland]], the [[Soviet Union]] and [[Hungary]]. The nations of Finland, Norway and Sweden all established national championships.<ref name="palmer_20">Palmer, Peter (1997). ''The Complete Orienteering Manual''. Wiltshire, England: The Crowood Press Ltd., {{ISBN|1-86126-095-4}}, p. 20.</ref> The Swedish national orienteering society, ''Svenska Orienteringsförbundet'', the first national orienteering society, was founded in 1936.<ref name=boga_2>{{cite book |last=Boga|first=Steven|title=Orienteering: The Sport of Navigating with Map & Compass |publisher=Stackpole Books|location=Mechanicsburg, Pennsylvania, USA |year=1997|edition=1|volume=1|pages=2|chapter=1|isbn=0-8117-2870-6}}</ref>
==Spread beyond Europe after World War II== {{Expand section|date=September 2008}}<!-- needs content on Oceania and Asia --> Following [[World War II]], orienteering spread throughout Europe, and to North America, [[Oceania]], and Asia. This spread was due in part to post-war travel by European orienteers, therefore more military people were using orienteering as part of a training method.
In North America, the first orienteering event took place in the [[United States]], at [[Dartmouth College]] in [[Hanover, New Hampshire]], in November 1941. It was organized by Piltti Heiskanen, a visiting teacher from Finland. Swedish orienteer and business man [[Bjorn Kjellström]], who moved to the [[United States]] in 1946, had a major influence on the sport there. In 1967, Norwegian Harald Wibye founded the first U.S. orienteering club, the [[Delaware Valley Orienteering Association]], which 30 years later was the largest orienteering club in the United States.<ref name=boga_3>{{cite book|last=Boga|first=Steven|title=Orienteering: The Sport of Navigating with Map & Compass|publisher=Stackpole Books|location=Mechanicsburg, Pennsylvania, USA|year=1997|edition=1|volume=1|pages=3–4|isbn=0-8117-2870-6}}</ref> In 1971, a group of orienteers led by members of the then four-year-old Quantico Orienteering Club founded the [[United States Orienteering Federation]].<ref name="boga_3" />
The [[Canadian Orienteering Federation]] was founded in 1967, and the first Canadian national orienteering championship was held at Gatineau Park in [[Ottawa]] on August 10, 1968.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.orienteering.ca/HISTORY.htm |title=History of the Canadian Orienteering Federation |last=Kirk |first=Colin |year=2006 |publisher=Canadian Orienteering Federation |accessdate=2006-02-22 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051027180102/http://orienteering.ca/HISTORY.htm |archivedate=2005-10-27 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The only [[World Orienteering Championships|World Championship]] to be held in North America took place at [[Harriman State Park (New York)|Harriman State Park]], [[New York (state)|New York]], USA, in 1993.
In Australia, the first orienteering event was held in 1955.{{Citation needed|date=May 2008}}
==Establishment as a world sport== <!-- redundant content collected here, needs rewrite --> The first international governing body for orienteering was the [[International Orienteering Federation]], which was formed by Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, East Germany, Finland, Hungary, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland and West Germany in 1961.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hickoksports.com/history/orienteering.shtml|title=Orienteering|date=2004-04-18|publisher=hickoksports.com|accessdate=2008-08-31|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080522131709/http://www.hickoksports.com/history/orienteering.shtml|archivedate=2008-05-22|df=}}</ref>
<!-- propose move: see talk --> Eleven countries sent representatives to an international conference in [[Sandviken]], Sweden, in 1949 that aimed to bring more consistent rules and mapping standards to the sport. The Norwegians and Swedes began producing new multi-color maps with [[cartography]] designed specifically for orienteering, in the 1950s.{{Citation needed|date=May 2008}} The International Orienteering Federation (IOF) was established in 1961 and the first world championships were held in 1966.{{Citation needed|date=May 2008}} The founding member societies represented the nations of [[Bulgaria]], [[Czechoslovakia]], [[Denmark]], the [[Federal Republic of Germany]], the [[German Democratic Republic]], Finland, Hungary, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland. By 1969, the IOF would represent 16 countries, including the first two non-European member societies representing [[Japan]] and [[Canada]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.momentech.com.au/droc/HistoryOrienteering.asp |title=Orienteering History |last=Dandenong Ranges Orienteering Club |publisher=Momentech Software Services |accessdate=2006-02-19 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060108211727/http://www.momentech.com.au/droc/HistoryOrienteering.asp |archivedate=2006-01-08 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
Eighty different national orienteering federations are member societies of the IOF today.<ref name=iof_nations>{{cite web|url=http://orienteering.org/about-the-iof/national-federations/|title=National Federations|publisher=International Orienteering Federation|accessdate=2016-02-16}}</ref> World championships were held biannually from 1961 to 2003, and are now held every year.
==References== {{Reflist|2}} *{{Cite news | last =Ryan | first =Rachel Estrada | date =September–October 2008 | title =Lost and Found | periodical =[[AAA World]] | publisher =[[AAA Mid-Atlantic]] | volume =10 | issue =5 | pages =18 | issn = | doi = | oclc = | postscript =<!--None-->}}
{{Orienteering|type=concepts}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:History Of Orienteering}} [[Category:Orienteering]] [[Category:History of sports by sport|Orienteering]]

{{Infobox Stadium | name = Steve Spurrier Field at
Kermit Tipton Stadium | nickname = | image = | former_names = | location = 1509 John Exum Pkwy. [[Johnson City, Tennessee|Johnson City]], [[Tennessee]] | coordinates = {{coord|36|19|32|N|82|22|10|W|type:edu|display=inline,title|format=dms}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 2010 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Johnson City Schools | operator = | surface = Artificial turf | construction_cost = | architect = | capacity = 6,600 | tenants = [[Science Hill High School|Science Hill Hilltoppers]] ([[Tennessee Secondary School Athletic Association|TSSAA]]) (2010–present)
[[East Tennessee State Buccaneers football|ETSU Buccaneers]] ([[NCAA Division I|NCAA D-I]]) (2015–2016)
Tri-Cities Otters ([[Premier Development League|PDL]]) (2016–present) }} '''[[Steve Spurrier]] Field at Kermit Tipton Stadium''' is a 6,600-capacity multi-use stadium on the campus of [[Science Hill High School]] in [[Johnson City, Tennessee]]. In addition to serving as home to the Hilltoppers, the stadium played host to the [[East Tennessee State Buccaneers football]] team while [[William B. Greene Jr. Stadium|their own facility]] was being built. Kermit Tipton Stadium was built to replace the aging Memorial Stadium located near [[Howard Johnson Field]]. {{East Tennessee State Buccaneers football navbox}} {{Premier Development League stadiums}} [[Category:High school football venues in the United States]] [[Category:Johnson City, Tennessee]] [[Category:Sports venues in Tennessee]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Tennessee]] [[Category:2010 establishments in Tennessee]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2010]] [[Category:American football venues in Tennessee]] [[Category:East Tennessee State Buccaneers football venues]]

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/185.49.168.78|185.49.168.78]] identified as test/vandalism using [[WP:STiki|STiki]]
revision.text:
{{about|the towsport|the surfsport|kneeboarding (surfsport)}} {{Cleanup rewrite|date=May 2009}} {{Unreferenced|date=July 2018}} [[File:Kneeboard backflip.webm|thumb|Kneeboard backflip]]<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Co-inventor Mike Murphy performs wake jump on Knee Ski, 1971.jpg|thumb|right|Co-inventor Mike Murphy performs wake jump on Knee Ski, 1971]] --> [[File:Kneeboarding.jpg|thumb|right|Kneeboarder]] '''Kneeboarding''' is an [[water|aquatic]] [[sport]] where the participant is towed on a buoyant, convex, and hydrodynamically shaped [[boardsport|board]] at a planing speed, most often behind a [[motorboat]]. Kneeboarding on a surf style board with fin(s) is also done in waves at the beach. In the usual configuration of a tow-sport kneeboard, riders kneel on their heels on the board, and secure themselves to the deck with an adjustable [[Velcro]] strap over their thighs. Most water ski kneeboards do not have fins to allow for easier surface spins. As in [[wakeboarding]] or [[water skiing]], the rider hangs onto a tow-rope. The advantages of kneeboarding versus other tow-sports seems to be an easier learning curve and a sense of being closer to the water when falls occur.
==History== Kneeboards were first produced commercially in the 1970s. While they were not widely popular at first, kneeboarding had become widespread by the mid-1970s. Today, kneeboarding remains popular, with sales of about 100,000 units per year.
As waterskiing gained popularity, riders also experimented with kneeling down on round plywood discs. Others tried kneeling on surfboards and some used purpose-built kneeboards designed specifically for riding waves, but the water ski kneeboard did not emerge as a product until the 1970s.
The first commercially available water ski kneeboard was Knee Ski, co-invented by Mike Murphy and Bud Hulst in 1972. Hulst had a background in surfing, manufacturing kneeboards for wave riding under the name of El Paipo. Murphy had been a professional show skier. The original Knee Ski was made from molded fiberglass, like a boat hull, and was neutrally buoyant. Each Knee Ski had a flat neoprene pad covering the entire deck, and a Velcro strap.
In 1973, John Taylor, a former Knee Ski employee, decided to make and sell his own boards under the name of Glide Slide. Taylor took a new approach, blow molding a plastic shell and filling it with foam. Unfortunately the teardrop design was unstable, and Glide Slide faltered as the [[1973 oil crisis]] slowed the water sports industry.
Danny Churchill, quarter mile speed ski record holder in 1974 and former Glide Slide employee, bought the company in the wake of the oil crisis. Churchill redesigned the Glide Slide to make it more stable and renamed the product Hydroslide in 1976. Churchill is most commonly known for popularizing the sport through advertising and promotions in the newly released full color water ski publications of the late 1970s and early 1980s.
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Former US Champ Tony Klarich performs wake back roll, 1989.jpg|thumb|right|Former US National Champ Tony Klarich performs wake back roll, 1989]] --> In the early 1980s the very first association for competition was formed called the International Kneeboard Association (IKA). Founded by Roland Hillier of Maitland, Florida, a former World Overall and Slalom Champion; National Slalom and Trick Champion; Masters Overall Water Ski Champion and three time Intercollegiate Overall Champion. Hillier created the rules and regulations for kneeboarding not only for boat towing method but also cableway towing. In boat towing the three competition events were tricks, slalom and wake crossing. A special event was also included to be called the "Flip-off" to see how many flips could be completed in twenty seconds. This proved to be quite popular with the spectators. In cableway competition, Roland designed the trick event which also included the use of small ramps for doing spins and flips. Calculations were needed to adjust for cableway towline length when the water levels changed. Roland Hillier also wrote and published the first book on kneeboarding called "Kneeboarding A - Z". After several National Championships, he produced and broadcast on ABC and, later, PBS of "The International Kneeboard Championships". This broadcast was the very first of its kind. The next year, Sea World of Orlando approached the IKA to hold a National Championship at their park, however, the original sponsors to the IKA would not be allowed to participate and Hillier felt strongly that supporters should be included and did not accept. The American Kneeboarding Association (AKA) was founded by another group of people after the International Kneeboard Association rejected the Sea World offer, and created their own form of competition. Eventually the AKA merged with USA WaterSki as one of its designated towable sports. ¹ [http://www.usawaterski.org/pages/divisions/kneeboard/kneeboardhist.htm Kneeboarding History]
One of the earliest types of kneeboarding is 'tourist kneeboarding'. In this type of kneeboarding, the rider begins on land, already strapped to the board. This type of kneeboarding is far easier than normal kneeboarding, usually done in a river or on a lake. Regular kneeboarding is far superior to "tourist kneeboarding" because you are already in the water and can take off faster.
==Description== Required equipment includes a tow rope, a kneeboard and a boat that can go about 15-20 mph (28–32 km/h). Also, most importantly, a certified life vest for safety. Kneeboarding starts are relatively simple, and the rider does not need to travel very quickly.
There are two basic grips – the palms-down grip and the baseball bat grip. For the palms-down grip the hands facing downward while holding the ski rope. For the Baseball Bat grip kneeboarders hold the handle just like a baseball bat.
==Tricks== Here is a list of kneeboarding tricks:
# Riding - Ride with your arms at full extension (this keeps your arms from tiring,) your knees in the divits, and the strap on relatively tight. # Turning - While riding, hold on tightly to the tow rope, and lean your body to one side. This should put the kneeboard on its edge, and take you outside of the boat's wake. To come back straight behind the boat, lean in the other direction. To turn more aggressively, pull in on the rope with your arms (the handle should be close to the hip,the opposite side from the side your turning to) and lean harder. # Side Slide/Butter Slide - Position yourself directly behind the boat with a palms-down grip. Rotate the board sideways without turning on edge - the board should slide. As you slide sideways, lean back so the boat doesn't pull you forward. It makes it much easier if you pull the handle and place it on your hip while you turn sideways. You should lean away from the boat just a little. # "Jumping the wake"- To jump the wake while on a kneeboard, simply cut hard out of the wake, get as far away from the boat as possible (to one side,) then use a progressively harder cut back toward the wake. Lean back slightly, and you will launch off the wake of the boat, sending you into the air. Make sure you hold the board flat by using your stomach muscles. # The ole - To perform this trick, you must combine the skills of balance and riding one-handed. You pull in the tow rope, pulling in hand-over-hand, until you are holding the rope roughly 6 feet beyond the handle. From there, you hold the rope in one hand, near your hip, and then swing the remainder of the rope, along with the handle, above your head # Surface 360 - This trick is very similar to the side slide. Slightly rotate to one side to build momentum, and then fully rotate in the opposite direction. If you are spinning to the right, release the rope with your right hand, spin, grab the rope again behind your back, and then pull yourself through to finish the 360. # Riding Backwards - You go through exactly the same motion as a 360, but instead of pulling yourself through the 360, you pause while both hands are behind your back. You must lean forward while riding backwards - leaning what is forward to the rider will push the nose down and the tail up. Otherwise, the tail could go under the water and flip the rider. # Wake Front-to-Back - Make a hard cut from outside the wake, using the palms-down grip. Right before you hit the wake, stop cutting and pop up in a jump, focusing on pushing your knees away from your chest to give you added height. As soon as you are airborne, rotate your body to the right and pull the handle to your hip. As you spin, keep a tight grip on the rope, and lean forward slightly. Keep leaning forward (away from the boat) as you hit the water. Once you have landed, you should be riding backwards, and can continue to ride with both hands at your hip. # Wake 360 front-to-front (wrapped) - While in the middle of the wake, pull yourself towards the boat, collecting the rope in one hand. Then, wrap the rope around your back, and hold onto the handle. Let go of the rope, and the friction of the rope straightening will spin you around. # Air (Ollie) - similar to the skateboarding trick of the same name, or a bunny hop in BMX, it is possible to jump without utilizing the wake. By pushing down against the water with your knees and simultaneously pulling the handle in provides more tension on the rope. Then pulling upwards with your legs, you can make the entire board leave the water. If this is combined with 'jumping' the wake, much greater heights can be achieved. # Back Roll - Make a hard cut toward the wake. One millisecond before you hit the wake, flatten out. Ride up the wake while resisting it (see wake jump). At the top of the wake, and not before, throw your shoulders sideways in the direction of your roll. At the same time, look back over your shoulder and pull the handle to your waist. Your momentum will take you around and then you just need to land. If you are coming up short, you are most likely throwing the trick too soon, letting your arms out, or not throwing the trick sideways. If you lean forward at all, you will lose your rotation momentum. # Switch 3 - The switch 3 is basically a wake 360 back except that you change the direction of rotation after 180 degrees. Make a hard cut toward the wake with a palms down grip. When you reach the trough, spin around 180 degrees. Rotate to the left if you're cutting to the right and rotate to the right if you're cutting to the left. Tuck the handle into your hip. Ride up the wake while resisting it to get a good pop. Once you are in the air and not sooner, spin back to the front. As you come around, keep the handle low and let your arms extend out. Once you reach the forward position, pull the handle to your waist again and spin backward in the opposite direction. Land backwards and use your second pop to spin back to the front. It's very important to keep the handle at your waist and your head up when landing. # Frontflip - Edge in hard, flatten out, pop off the wake and immediately throw your body straight down, keeping both hands on the handle and close to your hip. This will help with rotation and control.
==See also== * [[Aquaplaning (sport)]]
==External links== * [http://www.usawaterski.org/pages/divisions/kneeboard/kneeboardhist.htm Kneeboarding's History]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Kneeboarding (Towsport)}} [[Category:Towed water sports]] [[Category:Boardsports]] [[Category:Articles containing video clips]] [[Category:Kneeling]]

{{One source|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox rugby league representative team | Name = Latvia | Badge = Latvia national rugby league team logo.jpg | Badge_size = 100px | Nickname = | Governing body = Latvian Rugby League | Region = [[Rugby League European Federation|Europe]] | Coach = Steve Leonard ([[United Kingdom|GBR]]) | Captain = Jānis Zuments | RLIF Rank = 47 | Most caps = | Top try-scorer = | Top point-scorer = | pattern_la1=|pattern_b1=|pattern_ra1=||pattern_sh=|pattern_so= | leftarm1=FFFFFF|body1=FFFFFF|rightarm1=FFFFFFF|shorts1=CC0033|socks1=CC0033 | First international= {{rl|Estonia}} 38 - 54 {{rl-rt|Latvia}}
(21 October 2007, [[Tallinn]]) | Largest win = {{rl|Estonia}} 4 - 74 {{rl-rt|Latvia}}
(8 August 2009, [[Tallinn]]) | Largest loss = {{rl|Ukraine}} 112 - 0 {{rl-rt|Latvia}}
(18 September 2010, [[Kiev]] ) | World cup apps = | World cup first = | World cup best = }} The '''Latvia national rugby league team''' was established in 2008 to represent [[Latvia]] at [[rugby league football]], and initially competed in the [[Rugby League European Bowl|European Bowl]], for fourth-tier developing nations. They beat [[Estonia national rugby league team|Estonia]] in a two-game series and therefore won the inaugural tournament after Ukraine could not gain visas to travel. In 2009 they reached the second place after losing to [[Ukraine national rugby league team|Ukraine]] and defeating Estonia. In 2010 they played in the [[Rugby League European Shield|European Shield]], losing to [[Russia national rugby league team|Russia]] and Ukraine. After a hiatus of several years, Latvia will return to international competition on May 9, 2015 for the first match of the [[2017 Rugby League World Cup]] qualifying process, taking on [[Spain national rugby league team|Spain]] in a one-off knockout match to determine the final participants in the 'European C' section. ==All-time results record== {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! Team !! First Played !! Played !! Win !! Draw !! Loss !! Points For !! Points Against !! Last Meeting |- | {{rl|Estonia}}|| 2007 || 4 || 4 || 0 || 0 || 238 || 62 || 2009 |- | {{rl|Ukraine}}|| 2009 || 2 || 0 || 0 || 2 || 6 || 152 || 2010 |- | {{rl|Russia}}|| 2010 || 1 || 0 || 0 || 1 || 4 || 54 || 2010 |- | {{rl|Spain}}|| 2015 || 1 || 0 || 0 || 1 || 12 || 32 || 2015 |} ==Results== {{RLIF World Rankings|Latvia}} {|class=wikitable |- !Opponent !!Points !!Date !!Venue |- |[[Estonia national rugby league team|Estonia]] ||align=center|54 - 38 ||2007-10-21 ||[[Tallinn]] |- |[[Estonia national rugby league team|Estonia]] ||align=center|48 - 10 ||2008-06-28 ||[[Tallinn]] |- |[[Estonia national rugby league team|Estonia]] ||align=center|62 - 10 ||2008-08-03 ||[[Riga]] |- |[[Ukraine national rugby league team|Ukraine]] ||align=center|6 - 40 ||2009-07-24 ||[[Riga]] |- |[[Estonia national rugby league team|Estonia]] ||align=center|74 - 4 ||2009-08-08 ||[[Tallinn]] |- |[[Russia national rugby league team|Russia]] ||align=center|4 - 54 ||2010-07-31 ||[[Riga]] |- |[[Ukraine national rugby league team|Ukraine]] ||align=center|0 - 112 ||2010-09-18 ||[[Kiev]] |- |[[Spain national rugby league team|Spain]] ||align=center|32 - 12 ||2015-05-09 ||[[Riga]] |} ===World Cup=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- !colspan=9|[[Rugby League World Cup|World Cup record]] |- ! width=150 |Year ! width=150 |Round ! width=50 |Position ! width=50 |GP ! width=50 |W ! width=50 |L ! width=50 |D |- |{{flagicon|Australia}}{{flagicon|New Zealand}} [[2017 Rugby League World Cup|2017]]||rowspan=1 colspan=8| Failed to qualify |- |'''Total'''||'''0 Titles'''||'''0/13'''||'''0'''||'''0'''||'''0'''||'''0''' |} ===2017 Rugby League World Cup Qualifier=== {{Main|2017 Rugby League World Cup qualifying#Preliminary play-off}} On the 9th of May 2015, Latvia and [[Spain national rugby league team|Spain]] kicked off proceedings for the qualifying fixtures for the [[2017 Rugby League World Cup qualifying]]. It was a do or die match with the winner advancing to a qualifying group stage, already containing Malta and Greece, while the other would lose their chance of qualifying for their first ever World Cup. The Latvians' home advantage had no effect as they went down to the Spaniards by 20 points, ending their chance of participating in the 2017 Rugby League World Cup. ==Notable players of Latvian descent== * [[Euan Aitken]], whose paternal grandmother was born in [[Rēzekne]]{{cite web|date=20 April 2018|title=Goodbye Oma, I Love You|url=https://www.playersvoice.com.au/euan-aitken-goodbye-oma-love-you/|publisher=Players' Voice|accessdate=20 April 2018}}{{cite web|title=Regina Meinhold|url=https://oralhistories.moadoph.gov.au/regina-meinhold|publisher=Museum of Australian Democracy|accessdate=21 April 2018}}{{cite web|date=21 April 2018|title=Regina Meinhold: Obituary|url=http://tributes.canberratimes.com.au/obituaries/canberratimes-au/obituary.aspx?n=regina-meinhold&pid=188796746|publisher=Canberra Times|accessdate=21 April 2018}} ==See also== {{Portal|Rugby league}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Latvia-sport-stub}} {{Rugbyleague-team-stub}} {{Rugby League European Federation}} {{International Rugby League}} {{National sports teams of Latvia}} [[Category:National rugby league teams]] [[Category:National sports teams of Latvia]]

page.title: List of foreign Thai League 1 players

revision.text:
{{inc-sport}}
This is a list of foreign players in the [[Thai League 1]], which commenced play in 1996.
The List includes players from [[1996–97 Thailand Soccer League|1996]] to [[2018 Thai League|2018]]. Players of the current season are also included. All following players have played at least one Thai League game.
*'''National flag before the name:''' players who have represented their national football senior team in [[FIFA International Match Calendar|FIFA International Match]] and have at least one international appearance cap. *'''In bold:''' players who have played at least one Thai League game in the current season ([[2018 Thai League T1|2018]]), and are still at the clubs for which they have played. This does not include current players of a Thai League club who have not played a Thai League game in the current season. *As for dual citizen, nationality is listed under official registration. *The list of players by country is sorted by the year of transfer in. *The country that has more than 20 players played in Thai League will be categorized by year of transfer in.

{{Infobox venue | name = Mika Sports Arena | nickname = | image = Mika Arena, Yerevan.jpg | image_caption = | fullname = Mika Sports Arena | former_names = State Revenue Committee Sports Hall (2014-18) | location = [[Yerevan]], [[Armenia]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 2009 | renovated = 2016 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Government of Armenia | operator = Ministry of Sport and Youth Affairs | surface = Parquet floor | scoreboard = yes | construction_cost = | suites = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 1,200 | record_attendance = | dimensions = | tenants = [[Armenia national futsal team]] (2014–present)
[[Armenia national basketball team]] (2016–present)
[[Charbakh Yerevan Futsal Club|Charbakh Futsal]] (2015–present)
[[Armenia Travel Futsal Club|Armenia Travel futsal]] (2017–present)
[[Leo Futsal]] (2017–present) }} '''Mika Sports Arena''' ({{lang-hy|Միկա Մարզադահլիճ}}), is a multi-purpose [[arena|sports arena]] located in the [[Shengavit District]] of [[Yerevan]], the capital of [[Armenia]]. It has a capacity of 1,200 spectators. The arena was constructed in 2009 by the Mika Corporation Ltd., the owners of the currently-defunct football club [[Mika FC]]. It is located near the [[Mika Stadium]]. Mika Sports Arena is currently home to the [[Armenia national basketball team]]. It was also home to the short-lived [[Urartu BC]] basketball team during 2016. ==History== The construction of the Mika Sports Complex was launched in 2006 on the grounds of the former Araks sports complex. The football stadium was completed in 2008, while the indoor sports arena was put in service by 2009. The arena was owned by the Mika Corporation until 2014. However, on August 28, 2014, due to the accumulated debts of the owners, the ownership of the entire sport complex was transferred to the Government of Armenia for [[Armenian dram|AMD]] 9.045 billion (US$22 million).{{cite web|url=http://arka.am/en/news/sport/mika_sporting_facility_placed_under_management_of_armenian_finance_ministry/|publisher=arka.am|title=Mika sporting facility placed under management of Armenian finance ministry|accessdate=2016-11-08}} The arena is basically used for [[basketball]] matches, but it may also host [[handball]], [[futsal]] and [[volleyball]] matches. Mika Arena is among the regular venues of the [[Pan-Armenian Games]]. ==References== {{commons category|Mika Sports Arena}} {{reflist}} {{Yerevan landmarks}} {{coord|40|08|56|N|44|28|39|E|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mika}} [[Category:Buildings and structures in Yerevan]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Armenia]] [[Category:Sports venues in Yerevan]] [[Category:Futsal clubs in Armenia]] {{Armenia-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Infobox film | name = North Shore | image = North shore poster.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[William Phelps (director)|William Phelps]] | writer = [[Randal Kleiser]]
[[Tim McCanlies]]
[[William Phelps (director)|William Phelps]]| | starring = {{plainlist| * [[Matt Adler]] * [[Nia Peeples]] * [[John Philbin]] * [[Gerry Lopez]] * [[Gregory Harrison]] }} | producer = [[Bill Finnegan]]
[[Tim McCanlies]] | studio = [[Finnegan/Pinchuk Productions]] | distributor = [[Universal Pictures]] | released = August 14, 1987 | runtime = 96 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = $3,832,228 }} '''''North Shore''''' is a 1987 American [[action film|action]] [[drama (film and television)|drama]] [[surf film]] about Rick Kane ([[Matt Adler]]), a young [[surfer]] from a [[wave tank]] in [[Arizona]], who heads to surf the season on the [[North Shore (Oahu)|North Shore of O{{okina}}ahu]] to see if he has the skills to cut it as a pro surfer. As he progresses on his journey, he learns the qualities he possesses are not going to pull him through alone. ==Synopsis== Rick Kane is approximately 18 years old at the start of the film, having just graduated high school. He uses his winnings from a wave tank surfing contest in his native state of [[Arizona]] to fly to Hawaii for the summer before the start of college, in order to try to become a professional surfer. He takes a plane to [[Honolulu]] with plans to stay with a surfer that he met in Arizona six months previously. He finds the friend tending bar at a seedy gentlemen's club. At the bar Rick meets up with two pro surfers, Alex (Robbie Page)https://encyclopediaofsurfing.com/entries/page-robbie and Mark ([[Mark Occhilupo]]), and stays with them at the house of Lance Burkhart. In the morning, he goes out surfing with Alex and Mark and realizes that surfing in the ocean is totally different to surfing in a wave tank. He is not as good as he had initially thought. During this scene he gets in the way of Vince, played by real surfing legend [[Gerry Lopez]], who is leader of a local group named "The Hui" (wave slider club). This causes Vince to wipe out and leads to a confrontation where Rick is chased off the beach, after he realizes his stuff was stolen from the beach by a member of "The Hui". With nowhere to go, he fortuitously runs into Turtle ([[John Philbin]]). Kane meets and falls in love with Kiani ([[Nia Peeples]]), a beautiful local girl, coincidentally the cousin of Vince, who helps him acclimate to the local culture and customs. Turtle introduces him to Chandler ([[Gregory Harrison]]), a shaper and soul surfer, who teaches Rick about soul surfing and Rick masters the art of appreciating and riding the waves. Rick is a talented graphic artist who helps Chandler design a more contemporary logo for his surfboards. The film's antagonist is Lance Burkhart ([[Laird Hamilton]]), a famous, top-ranked surfer whose competitive and materialistic values conflict with the spiritual teachings of Chandler ("You still have a single-fin-mentality"). The film climaxes with a surf contest on [[Banzai Pipeline]] as Rick ends up competing against Lance in a duel of skills and beliefs. ==Professional surfers== North Shore features professional surfers [[Shaun Tomson]], [[Gerry Lopez]] ("Vince"), [[Laird Hamilton]] ("Lance Burkhart"), [[Mark Occhilupo]], [[Robbie Page]] ("Alex Rogers"), [[Mark Foo]], [[Derek Ho]], [[Hans Hedemann]], [[Ken Bradshaw]], [[Christian "the KID" Fletcher]], [[Lord James Blears]] and several others. The character of Rick Kane was loosely based on Connecticut born surfer Benjamin "Barney" Partyka. The first-ever professional surfer, [[Corky Carroll]], plays a competition announcer in the film. ==Connections to real life== Laird Hamilton's adoptive father Bill Hamilton was a surfboard shaper and glasser on [[Oahu]] in the 1960s and 1970s and owned a small business. Bill was handmaking custom, high-performance surfboards for the Oahu North Shore big wave riders of the era, similar to the character Chandler in the film. In reality, Laird is a big wave rider and loathes competition like the Chandler character does. ==References== ==External links== * {{IMDb title|id=0093648|title=North Shore}} * {{Mojo title|northshore}} * {{Rotten Tomatoes|north_shore}} {{DEFAULTSORT:North Shore (Film)}} [[Category:1987 films]] [[Category:1980s sports films]] [[Category:1980s drama films]] [[Category:Surfing films]] [[Category:Films set in Hawaii]] [[Category:American sports films]] [[Category:American drama films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films shot in Hawaii]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Universal Pictures films]]

267 Shanshan Feng (2015) | to-par = −21 ''as above'' | current_champion = {{flagicon|USA}} [[Angel Yin]] }} {{Location map |UAE |relief = 1 |label = Dubai |lat = 25.09 |long = 55.15 |caption = Location in [[United Arab Emirates]] |float = |background= |width = 240 }} The '''Omega Dubai Ladies Classic '''is a professional [[golf]] tournament on the [[Ladies European Tour]] (LET) that was played for the first time in October 2006.{{cite web |url=http://www.ladieseuropeantour.com/content/let_content_feature.php?Id=5786&PHPSESSID=325909e49a36011bc15659eb8658fc14 |title=LET announces Dubai Ladies Masters |publisher=Ladies European Tour |first=Bethan |last=Cutler |date=26 May 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930185013/http://www.ladieseuropeantour.com/content/let_content_feature.php?Id=5786&PHPSESSID=325909e49a36011bc15659eb8658fc14 |archivedate=30 September 2007}} Its prize fund of [[Euro|€]]500,000 made it the fourth most valuable tournament on the LET. Promoted and organised by golf in Dubai, the tournament is played on the Majlis course at [[Emirates Golf Club]], which also hosts the [[Omega Dubai Desert Classic]] on the men's [[European Tour]]. Since 2009, [[Omega SA|Omega]], a luxury [[watch]] company based in Switzerland, has been the title sponsor of the tournament. [[Annika Sörenstam]] won the event the first two times it was played. Sörenstam beat out [[Karrie Webb]] in 2006, and in 2007 defeated [[Iben Tinning]] by two shots. The 2008 event, which was Sörenstam's final tournament before her retirement, was won by [[Germany]]'s [[Anja Monke]]. The 2016 event was shortened to 54 holes after caddie Maximilian Zechmann collapsed and died during the first round.{{cite news |url=http://www.espn.com/golf/story/_/id/18225583/caddie-dies-collapse-ladies-european-tour-event |title=Caddie dies, 1st round stopped and event shortened in Dubai |work=ESPN |agency=Associated Press |date=7 December 2016}} ==Winners== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:95%" !Year||Dates || Champion||Country||Score|| To par ||Margin

{{Infobox sport | name = Padbol | image = Logo Padbol.jpg | imagesize = 150px | caption = | union = FIPA | union UK = | nickname = Padbol | first = 2008, La Plata | country/region = | registered = | clubs = | contact = | team = Doubles | mgender = | category = Outdoor/Indoor | equipment = | venue = Padbol court | obsolete = | olympic = | paralympic = }}
'''Padbol''' is a fusion sport created in La Plata in 2008.<ref>http://www.padbol.com/en/padbol.php?paisregion=-1p-1p2</ref> It is currently played in [[Argentina]], [[Uruguay]], [[Mexico]], [[Spain]], [[Italy]], [[Portugal]], [[Sweden]], [[Romania]], [[Australia]], [[France]], [[Denmark]], [[Switzerland]], [[Panama]] and [[United States]].
==History== Padbol was created in 2008 by Gustavo Miguens in [[La Plata]], [[Argentina]]. The first track was laid in 2011 and elsewhere in Argentina such Rojas, Punta Alta, Buenos Aires. Then tracks in Spain, Uruguay and Italy and more recently were added in Portugal, Sweden, Mexico, Romania and England. Australia, Bolivia and France are newest countries.
In 2013 was the first Padbol World Cup in La Plata. The champions were the Spanish pair, Ocaña and Palacios.
In 2014 was the second edition in [[Alicante]], [[Spain]]. The champions were the Spanish pair Ramón and Hernández.
The third edition took place at [[Punta del Este]], [[Uruguay]] , in 2016
== Rules ==
=== Track === The playing area is a rectangle 10 meters long and 6 meters wide (inside measurements). It is divided transversely by a network that is suspended by a wire of a maximum diameter of 1 cm, whose ends are subject to two support posts, and their inner faces coincide with the lateral boundaries of the court. in each funds of the playing area there is a pediment and two side walls attached to it. The gable and the sidewalls should be at least 2.50 meters and be equal to each other. The net height is between 90 and 100 centimeters in the center and 100 cm maximum at the ends. Must be at least one access to the track with a minimum width of 0.60 meters and a height of 2 meters per side. It may or may not have a door.
=== Areas === [[File:Areas de juego Padbol.JPG|thumb|Areas on the track]] There are three zones : Service Zone, Reception Zone and Red Zone.
Service zone : This is where the server must meet to perform their serves and is bounded by the line is 3.25 meters in the network, the sidewalls and the bottom wall.
Reception area : Is located between the network, the central service line, the line that goes from side to side of the track (width) and side glass and/or close the perimeter wall. The lines marked on the floor are included in the valid Box for long.
Red zone : The area that forms a meter for each side's net, delineated by a line between cut and breadth of the entire court. It must be red.
=== Ball === The ball shall have a uniform outer surface and shall be white or yellow. Its perimeter is 670 mm, and it should be of polyurethane; its weight can range from 380 grams to 400 grams.
== Summary ==
* '''Players:''' 4. Played in a doubles format. * '''Serves:''' Serve must be underhand. A second serve is allowed in the event a fault, as in tennis. * '''Score:''' Scoring method is the same as in tennis. Matches are best of three sets. * '''Ball:''' Soccer ball but smaller * '''Court:''' There are two styles of courts: indoor and outdoor * '''Walls:''' Walls or fences are part of the game.
== Tournaments ==
=== Padbol World Cup === [[File:Partido de Padbol.jpg|thumb|Match in World Cup 2014 - Argentina vs Spain]] In March 2013 it developed the first World Cup in La Plata, Argentina. Participated sixteen couples of Argentina, Uruguay, Italy and Spain. In the Final, Ocaña/Palacios won 6-1/6-1 against Saiz/Rodriguez.
The second Padbol World Cup was held in November 2014 in Alicante, Spain . Participated 15 couples from seven countries (Argentina, Uruguay, Mexico, Spain, Italy, Portugal and Sweden). Ramón/Hernández won the final 6-4/7-5 against Ocaña/Palacios.
The third edition will be held in Punta del Este, Uruguay, in 2016.

Yoke | image3 = File:Owner F Bonelli.svg | alt3 = White, red seams, stars on sleeves, check cap | caption3 = Sagar Pride }} {{Jockey colours footer}} The '''Poule d'Essai des Pouliches''' is a [[Conditions races|Group 1]] [[Flat racing|flat]] [[Horse racing|horse race]] in [[France]] open to three-year-old [[thoroughbred]] [[Filly|fillies]]. It is run over a distance of 1,600 metres (about 1 mile) at [[Longchamp Racecourse|Longchamp]] in May. It is France's equivalent of the [[1,000 Guineas Stakes|1,000 Guineas]], a famous race in England. ==History== ===Origins=== The [[Poule d'Essai des Poulains#Poule d'Essai|Poule d'Essai]], an event for three-year-old colts and fillies, was established in France in 1840. It was inspired by two races in England, the [[2000 Guineas Stakes|2000 Guineas]] (for colts and fillies) and the 1,000 Guineas (for fillies only). The race was initially staged at the [[Champ de Mars]]. Its first running was over one full circuit of the track (about 2,000 metres). It was cut to a three-quarter lap (1,500 metres) in 1841. It was cancelled due to insufficient entries in 1843 and 1844. The Poule d'Essai was transferred to Longchamp in 1857. It was extended to 1,600 metres in 1867.{{cite web | title = 1868 Poule d'Essai | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=5-UNAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA324&img=1&zoom=3&hl=en&sig=ACfU3U3c0zBqSudOQZDO2sjvQ6jM3c5nFQ&ci=443%2C66%2C480%2C283&edge=0 | work = Ruff's Guide to the Turf for 1869 | accessdate = 28 April 2013}} It was abandoned because of the [[Franco-Prussian War]] in 1871. It continued to be run until 1882.{{cite news | title = 1882 Poule d'Essai | url = http://gallica.bnf.fr/proxy?method=R&ark=bpt6k278179d.f3&l=5&r=3516,3384,712,422 | language = French | newspaper = [[Le Figaro]] | date = 24 April 1882 | accessdate = 28 April 2013}} ===Modern version=== The Poule d'Essai des Pouliches was created in 1883, when the Poule d'Essai was divided into two separate races.{{cite news | title = 1883 Poule d'Essai des Pouliches | url = http://gallica.bnf.fr/proxy?method=R&ark=bpt6k278547v.f3&l=5&r=776,3352,501,415 | language = French | newspaper = Le Figaro | date = 23 April 1883 | accessdate = 28 April 2013}} The "Pouliches" was restricted to fillies, and the [[Poule d'Essai des Poulains]] was reserved for colts. The events were cancelled throughout World War I, with no runnings from 1915 to 1918. There were two 1,800-metre replacement races at [[Chantilly Racecourse|Chantilly]] in 1917.{{cite news | title = Courses à Chantilly | url = http://gallica.bnf.fr/proxy?method=R&ark=bpt6k537260b.f4&l=5&r=332,1228,340,488 | language = French | newspaper = [[Le Gaulois]] | date = 22 May 1917 | accessdate = 28 April 2013}} The version for fillies was called the Critérium d'Essai des Pouliches.{{cite news | title = 1917 Critérium d'Essai des Pouliches | url = http://gallica.bnf.fr/proxy?method=R&ark=bpt6k537260b.f4&l=5&r=3402,1238,255,485 | newspaper = Le Gaulois | date = 22 May 1917 | accessdate = 28 April 2013}} The "Pouliches" and "Poulains" were not run in the spring of 1940, but a substitute combining both races took place at [[Auteuil Hippodrome|Auteuil]] in October. Titled the Prix d'Essai, it was won by the colt [[Djebel]].{{cite news | title = Djebel enlève le Prix d'Essai | url = http://gallica.bnf.fr/proxy?method=R&ark=bpt6k586908d.f3&l=5&r=3424,3632,1652,608 | language = French | newspaper = [[Le Matin (France)|Le Matin]] | date = 28 October 1940 | accessdate = 28 April 2013}} The Poule d'Essai des Pouliches was held at [[Tremblay Park|Le Tremblay]] in 1943,{{cite news | title = Résultats de samedi, au Tremblay | url = http://gallica.bnf.fr/proxy?method=R&ark=bpt6k587727c.f3&l=5&r=1396,3076,614,310 | newspaper = Le Matin | date = 17 May 1943 | accessdate = 28 April 2013}} and [[Maisons-Laffitte Racecourse|Maisons-Laffitte]] in 1944 and 1945.{{cite news | title = La journée des Poules d'Essai à Maisons-Laffitte | url = http://gallica.bnf.fr/proxy?method=R&ark=bpt6k5880305.f4&l=5&r=304,1892,612,602 | language = French | newspaper = Le Matin | date = 13 May 1944 | accessdate = 28 April 2013}} The present race grading system was introduced in 1971, and the event was given Group 1 status. It was switched from Longchamp's middle course (moyenne piste) to the main course (grande piste) in 1987. The leading horses from the Poule d'Essai des Pouliches sometimes go on to compete in the [[Prix de Diane]]. Twenty-six fillies have won both races. The most recent was Avenir Certain in 2014. ==Records== {{refbegin}} '''Leading [[jockey]] (8 wins):''' * [[Freddy Head]] – ''Ivanjica (1975), Riverqueen (1976), Dancing Maid (1978), Three Troikas (1979), Silvermine (1985), Miesque (1987), Matiara (1995), Always Loyal (1997)'' '''Leading [[Horse trainer|trainer]] (7 wins):''' * [[Charles Semblat]] – ''Esmeralda (1942), Caravelle (1943), Palencia (1944), Corteira (1948), Coronation / Galgala (1949), Corejada (1950), Djelfa (1951)'' * [[Criquette Head-Maarek]] – ''Three Troikas (1979), Silvermine (1985), Baiser Vole (1986), Ravinella (1988), Matiara (1995), Always Loyal (1997), Special Duty (2010)'' '''Leading owner (8 wins):''' * [[Marcel Boussac]] – ''Esmeralda (1942), Caravelle (1943), Palencia (1944), Corteira (1948), Coronation / Galgala (1949), Corejada (1950), Djelfa (1951), Apollonia (1956)'' {{refend}} ==Winners since 1970== {| class = "sortable" | border="1" cellpadding="0" style="border-collapse: collapse; font-size:90%" |- bgcolor="#77dd77" align="center" ! Somarriba | manager = | league = | season = | position = | pattern_la1=|pattern_b1=_whitearmpits|pattern_ra1= | leftarm1=ff0000|body1=ff0000|rightarm1=ff0000|shorts1=ffffff|socks1=ffffff }} '''Scorpión FC''' is a [[Nicaragua]]n [[Football (soccer)|football]] team. It is based in [[Chinandega]]. ==History== In summer 2004 Scorpión was promoted to Nicaragua's second division.[http://archivo.elnuevodiario.com.ni/2004/octubre/21-octubre-2004/deportes/deportes-20041021-03.html Scorpion por ascenso] - El Nuevo Diario {{es|icon}} They played in the [[Primera División de Nicaragua]] in 2006/07 but encountered financial problems[http://impreso.elnuevodiario.com.ni/2007/01/02/deportes/37684 Scorpion se desintegra] - El Nuevo Diario {{es|icon}} and were relegated in the end of the season and demoted to the Third Division since they failed to show up for two league games.[http://impreso.elnuevodiario.com.ni/2007/04/24/deportes/46997 “Scorpion abandonó”] - El Nuevo Diario {{es|icon}}[http://www.rsssf.com/tablesn/nica07.html Nicaragua 2006/07] - RSSSF ==Notable players== * {{flagicon|ARG}} Carlos Javier Martino * {{flagicon|ARG}} Gabriel Álvarez * {{flagicon|NCA}} [[Carlos Alonso (Nicaraguan footballer)|Carlos Alonso]] (2006-2007)[http://impreso.elnuevodiario.com.ni/2006/08/01/deportes/25483 Alonso vuelve a Chinandega] - El Nuevo Diario {{es|icon}} * {{flagicon|NCA}} [[Samuel Wilson (footballer)|Samuel Wilson]] (2004-2006) ==Notable coaches== * {{flagicon|NCA}} Eduardo Alonso (2004) * {{flagicon|ARG}} Carlos Sánchez * {{flagicon|NCA}} Martín Mena ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Primera División de Nicaragua}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Scorpion Fc}} [[Category:Football clubs in Nicaragua]] {{Nicaragua-footyclub-stub}}

{{coord|1|25|36.21|N|103|47|18.19|E|display=title|region:SG_type:edu}} [[File:Singapore Sports School 20, Jul 07.JPG|thumb|right|Singapore Sports School]] '''Singapore Sports School''' is a Specialised Independent School in [[Singapore]] that offers an integrated sports and academic programme for secondary and post-secondary students. The school was officially opened on 2 April 2004 by [[Goh Chok Tong]], Singapore’s second Prime Minister. Singapore Sports School is under the purview of the [[Ministry of Culture, Community and Youth]].<ref>{{cite web|title=MCCY - About us - Our Agencies|url=https://www.mccy.gov.sg/en/About-us.aspx#Our-agencies|website=www.mccy.gov.sg}}</ref>
[[File:Logo of the Singapore Sports School.jpg|thumb|Singapore Sports School logo]]
==Management== Moo Soon Chong was the founding principal of Singapore Sports School.<ref>{{cite news|title=Sports school trials under way|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/today20030807-1.2.49.5|work=Today|date=7 August 2003}}</ref> He was assisted by Chua Choon Seng, Director of Corporate Services and Dr Irwin Seet, Director of Sports, Seah Poh Chua, Director of Academics and School Administration, who was Dean of the Academic Wing then, and a core team.
Moo retired on 14 December 2007 and Mrs Deborah Tan was appointed principal of Singapore Sports School on 15 December 2007.<ref>{{cite news|title=S'pore Sports School to get new principal next year|url=http://www.asiaone.com/News/AsiaOne%2BNews/Singapore/Story/A1Story20071010-29241.html|work=The Straits Times|date=10 October 2007}}</ref> Mrs Tan was appointed to a senior position at the Ministry of Education on 14 December 2013.
Tan Teck Hock is the new principal of Singapore Sports School. Tan has served in the Education Service since 1992. He was principal of Yishun Town Secondary School from December 1999 to December 2005 and principal of Serangoon Junior College from December 2006 to December 2010. Tan was the founding Principal of the Physical Education and Sports Teacher Academy in 2010.
[[File:Singapore Sports School 9, Jul 07.JPG|thumb|right|One of the [[Olympic size swimming pool]]s]]
==Singapore 2010 Youth Olympics Games== Singapore Sports School was the venue of the Aquatics (Swimming), Modern Pentathlon and Shooting.{{cn|date=January 2018}}
==National Youth Sports Institute == The National Youth Sports Institute (NYSI) is a youth-centric and youth-focused sporting organisation that aims to value-add and positively impact the Singapore youth sports ecosystem. Initiated by the Ministry of Culture, Community and Youth.NYSI works closely with the Singapore Sports School and Singapore Sports Institute to drive youth sports development through four functional areas: Talent Identification and Development, Youth Coaching, Sports Science and Athlete Life Management.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nysi.org.sg/about-us|title=ABOUT US|website=www.nysi.org.sg|access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref>
==Notable alumni== * [[Calvin Kang]]: Olympian (Athletics, Sprinter) * [[Dipna Lim Prasad]]: Olympian (Athletics, Hurdler) * [[Mylene Ong]]: Olympian (Swimming) * [[Tao Li]]: Olympian (Swimming) * [[Narelle Kheng]]: Actress and Singer, member of band Sam Willows * [[Benjamin Kheng]]: Actor and Singer, member of band Sam Willows * [[Ben Davis (footballer)|Ben Davis]]: Footballer for [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]]

{{good article}} {{Infobox video game |title = Skeet Shoot |image = File:Skeet Shoot Coverart.png |developer = [[Games by Apollo]] |publisher = [[Games by Apollo]] |designer = Ed Salvo<ref name="giantlist">{{cite web|title=The Giant List of Classic Game Programmers|url=http://dadgum.com/giantlist/|last1=Hague|first1=James}}</ref> |released = December 1981<ref name=gutmon/> |genre = Sports ([[skeet shooting]]) |modes = [[Single-player]], [[two-player video game|two-player]] alternating |platforms = [[Atari 2600]] }} '''''Skeet Shoot''''' is a [[skeet shooting]] [[video game]] for the [[Atari 2600]] and the first game released by [[Games by Apollo]] in December 1981.<ref name=gutmon/> Players assume the role of a skeet shooter shooting [[clay pigeon shooting|clay pigeons]]. There is a two-player mode where the players alternate.
''Skeet Shoot'' was developed by programmer Ed Salvo<ref name="giantlist"/> in his [[Iowa]] home and purchased by Pat Roper under the newly formed Apollo. Despite negative reviews, it was a financial success, and led to Salvo's continuation with the company, where he became Director of Development.
==Gameplay== [[File:Skeet Shoot gameplay.png|thumb|left|Gameplay; the shooter is seen at the bottom.]] The player controls a skeet shooter who is shooting clay pigeons. By pressing the button on the controller, a clay pigeon is sent out and pressing the button again will shoot; moving the joystick changes the gun's angle. A point is earned if the bullet hits. Difficulty varieties adjust the speed of the pigeons.<ref name=Allgame>{{cite web|title=Skeet Shoot|url=http://www.allgame.com/game.php?id=8351|website=[[AllGame]]|publisher=[[All Media Network]]|date=February 18, 2003|accessdate=July 1, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141114184850/http://www.allgame.com/game.php?id=8351|archivedate=November 14, 2014}}</ref>
Two two-player gameplay variations exist and are activated by modifying the Atari 2600's difficulty switches. There is an alternating version where players take turns shooting the clay pigeons, and another variation features one player shooting while the other controls the angle of the clay pigeons. Other variables that can be changed are the position of the shooter and the direction the bird will enter the screen from.<ref name=Allgame/>
==Development== Ed Salvo developed ''Skeet Shoot'' independently. Salvo had self-taught himself to program for the 2600 after purchasing an [[Atari 800]]; the dealer wanted a [[flight simulator]] for the 2600 so he contracted Salvo to make one. The game was never released as the dealer had lost interest. According to Salvo, the development of ''Skeet Shoot'' took him around a month at night in his home to finish. After his friend sent him an advertisement from a Dallas newspaper by newly founded studio [[Games by Apollo]] that asked for programmers, he contacted Apollo founder Pat Roper and showed him ''Skeet Shoot''.<ref name=salv>{{cite web|last1=Stilphen|first1=Scott|title=DP Interviews... Ed Salvo|url=http://www.digitpress.com/library/interviews/interview_ed_salvo.html|website=Digital Press|accessdate=June 7, 2014|date=December 5, 2010}}</ref> Roper decided that ''Skeet Shoot'' was a good enough game for a first time.<ref name=gutmon>{{cite web|last1=Gutmon|first1=Don|title=Trouble in a video game company|url=https://archive.org/stream/Electronic_Fun_with_Computer_Games_Vol_01_No_03_1983-01_Fun_Games_Publishing_US/Electronic_Fun_with_Computer__Games_Vol_01_No_03_1983-01_Fun__Games_Publishing_US#page/n61/mode/1up|website=[[Electronic Fun with Computers & Games]]|publisher=Fun & Games Publishing|accessdate=July 1, 2014|date=January 1983|volume=1|number=3|page=62}}</ref> He offered Salvo a job at Apollo, which Salvo declined, believing it would be too risky. When Salvo returned to his Iowa home, Roper contacted him and told him he would buy ''Skeet Shoot'' for five thousand dollars which Salvo accepted.<ref name=salv/>
''Skeet Shoot'' still had [[glitch]]es when it was released; one caused the image to flip vertically. Salvo learned of the glitch and fixed it, and the only cartridges that bear the bug are European versions.<ref name=salv/>
==Reception== Reviews were negative, as Apollo's publicist Emmit Crawford acknowledged.<ref name=Crawford>{{cite web|title=Apollo, like its namesake, shoots for the video-gaming stars!|url=https://archive.org/stream/Videogaming_Illustrated_1982-08_Ion_International_US#page/n5/mode/2up|website=[[Videogaming Illustrated]]|publisher=Ion International|accessdate=June 30, 2014|date=August 1982|page=7–8|issn=0739-4373}}</ref> Crawford believed that the reason people did not like ''Skeet Shoot'' was because it did not provide enough challenge for most video game players and that the company had distributed it in too much of a hurry.<ref>{{cite web|title=Apollo Shoots for the Moon|url=https://archive.org/stream/Video_Games_Volume_1_Number_02_1982-10_Pumpkin_Press_US#page/n15/mode/2up|website=Video Games|publisher=Pumpkin Press|accessdate=July 1, 2014|date=October 1982|volume=1|number=2|pages=16, 18}}</ref> He later said that "All in all, Skeet Shoot wasn't a spectacular game to start off with."<ref name=Crawford/> Despite the poor publicity, the game sold very well.<ref name=AGH>{{cite web|title=AGH – Third Party Profile: Apollo|url=http://www.atarihq.com/2678/3party/apollo.html|website=Atari Gaming Headquarters|accessdate=June 30, 2014|date=January 23, 2005}}</ref>
Author Brett Alan Weiss wrote that ''Skeet Shoot'' was "a shoddily programmed, graphically primitive game" and said that the poor controls and difficulty levels rendered the game "virtually worthless".<ref>{{cite book|last=Weiss|first=Brett|title=Classic Home Video Games, 1972–1984: A Complete Reference Guide|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BzxTtml8Jq4C&pg=PA104|date=March 7, 2012|publisher=McFarland & Company|isbn=978-0-7864-8755-4|page=104}}</ref> A writer for ''Atari HQ'' called it a mediocre game.<ref name=AGH/> Lee Peppas of ''[[ANALOG Computing]]'' remarked that "Atari & Activision have nothing to fear from the graphics on this first release."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Peppas|first1=Lee|title=VCS Update|url=https://archive.org/stream/analog-computing-magazine-05/Analog_Computing_05_1982-01_Graphics#page/n39/mode/2up|website=[[ANALOG Computing]]|accessdate=July 1, 2014|date=January 1982|number=5|page=37}}</ref> ''[[TV Gamer]]'' opined it was one of the worst games for the system, saying that it was boring and criticizing the fact that it was difficult to hit the skeet.<ref>{{cite web|title=Skeet Shoot|url=https://archive.org/stream/TV_Gamer_1983-06_Boytonbrook_GB#page/n29/mode/2up|website=[[TV Gamer]]|publisher=Boytonbrook|accessdate=July 1, 2014|date=June 1983|page=31}}</ref>
Mark Androvich of ''Classic Gamer Magazine'' was similarly negative, writing "Games by Apollo released a couple of decent games before going bankrupt, but you never would have guessed that anyone at the company knew how to program the Atari 2600 judging by their debut game." Androvich opined that while the game was playable, it was not "a step in the right direction" for Apollo.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Androvich|first1=Mark|title=Five Atari 2600 Games Worse Than E.T.|url=https://archive.org/stream/Classic_Gamer_Magazine_Volume_3_Issue_1_2010_Classic_Gamer_US#page/n19/mode/2up|website=[[Classic Gamer]]|accessdate=July 7, 2014|year=2010||volume=3|issue=1|page=21}}</ref>
==Aftermath== After ''Skeet Shoot'', Salvo signed a contract that led to the creation of ''[[Spacechase]]''. Eventually, Salvo became Apollo's Director of Development and was given the job of hiring 25 programmers to work on Apollo's games.<ref name=salv/> Apollo went on to release seven other games after ''Skeet Shoot''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Games By Apollo|url=http://www.allgame.com/company.php?id=102&tab=developed|website=[[AllGame]]|publisher=[[All Media Network]]|accessdate=July 1, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141116160607/http://www.allgame.com/company.php?id=102&tab=developed|archivedate=November 16, 2014 }}</ref> One year later, the studio eventually filed for [[Chapter 11 bankruptcy]] on November 12, 1982, due to pressure from its advertising agency, [[Benton & Bowles]]. Apollo owed the company $2.5 million (half of its total debt). Although Roper expected Apollo to return in "smaller form",<ref>{{cite news|title=Vid Game Firm Apollo Files Chapter XI|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=WiQEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PT62|accessdate=June 30, 2014|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|date=December 4, 1982|volume=94|number=48|issn=0006-2510}}</ref> the company closed in 1983 after reorganization attempts failed.<ref name="AGH"/>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{Portal|Video games}} * ''[https://archive.org/details/atari_2600_skeet_shoot_1981_apollo_-_games_by_apollo_ed_salvo_ap-1001 Skeet Shoot]'' at the [[Internet Archive]] Console Living Room

[[Machakos]], Kenya | capacity = | season = | pattern_la1= | pattern_la2= | pattern_la3 = | pattern_b2= | pattern_b3 = | pattern_ra1= | pattern_ra2= | pattern_ra3 = | pattern_sh3 = | pattern_so3 = | leftarm1= ffffff | leftarm2= 0000FF | leftarm3 = | body1= ffffff | body2=0000FF | body3 = | rightarm1= ffffff | rightarm2= 0000FF | rightarm3 = | shorts1= 0000ff | shorts2= FFFFFF | shorts3 = | socks1= 0000ff | socks2= FFFFFF | socks3 = | clubname = | image = Sofapaka.png | caption = | fullname = Sote kama Familia kwa Pamoja Kuafikia Azimio Football Club | founded = 2004 | dissolved = | chairman = {{flagicon|COD}} Elly Kalekwa | mgrtitle = Head coach | manager = Sam Timbe | league = [[Kenyan Premier League]] | position = 3rd | pattern_b1= | pattern_name3 = | firstgame = | largestwin = | worstdefeat = | topscorer = | fansgroup = | honours = | American = }} '''Sofapaka Football Club''' (Sofapaka: '''So'''te kama '''Fa'''milia kwa '''Pa'''moja '''K'''uafikia '''A'''zimio – [[Kiswahili]]: ''We as a Family together to achieve a goal'') is a football club, based in [[Nairobi]]. They play their home games at the [[Nyayo National Stadium|Kenyatta Stadium]], [[Machakos]], Kenya ==History== The club originates from the men’s fellowship of the MAOS Ministries football team founded in 2002, which took part in inter-church competitions. In 2004, Elly Kalekwa took over the team and formed Sofapaka, and eventually joined the [[Kenyan Nationwide League|Nationwide league]].[http://www.sofapaka.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=70&Itemid=75 Sofapaka history] The team won the [[FKF Cup|President's Cup]] in 2007, while still playing in the Nationwide League. ==Achievements== *'''[[Kenyan Premier League]]: 1''' :: 2009. *'''[[Kenyan President's Cup]]: 3''' :: 2007, 2010, [[2014 FKF President's Cup|2014]]. *'''[[KPL Top 8 Cup]]: 0''' revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}} {{Multiple issues| {{Refimprove|date=December 2009}} {{Update|date=August 2013}} }} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Stadio Comunale Sant'Elia | nickname = | image = [[File:Trib centrale sant elia.jpg|300px]]| location = [[Cagliari]], Italy | broke_ground = 1965| opened = 1970 | renovated = 1989, 2003, 2013| closed = 2017| demolished = 2017–2019| owner = Municipality of [[Cagliari]]| operator = | surface = Grass
105x66.5m| construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[Cagliari Calcio]] (1970–2017)| seating_capacity = 40,919 original structure / 16,000 provisional stand| }} '''Stadio Comunale Sant'Elia''' was a [[Association football|football]] stadium in [[Cagliari]], Italy. It is best known for having been the home of [[Cagliari Calcio]]. It hosted three matches during the [[1990 FIFA World Cup]]. The stadium had an initially capacity of 60,000 spectators, reduced to 40,919 in 1990, and then 23,834 and finally 16,000 spectators with a provisional stand. Its construction began in 1970, following [[Cagliari Calcio]]'s first and so far only [[Scudetto]], thus taking the place of the old [[Stadio Amsicora|Amsicora Stadium]]. The stadium could accommodate up to about 60,000 spectators (the record attendance being approximately 70,000, was recorded against [[AS Saint-Étienne|Saint Etienne]]). The stadium subsequently underwent major changes and restructuring for the [[1990 FIFA World Cup]]. The maximum capacity of Sant'Elia was reduced to 40,919 spectators. [[File:Stadio Sant'Elia -Cagliari -Italy-23Oct2008.jpg|left|thumb|Aerial view]] The Sant'Elia was also used for sporting events outside football such as the Terra Sarda athletics meet. Before the [[Serie B 2002-03|2002–03]] season, also due to the reduced number of fans following the poor form of the team, long reduced to yo-yoing between [[Serie A]] and [[Serie B|B]], the stadium was restructured again. Over the athletics track, a new stand was built, behind the goals so as to reduce the distance between the terrace and the playing field, with the central terraces remaining intact. The new format of the stadium, which almost halved its maximum capacity to 23,486 seats, came under harsh criticism. [[Cagliari Calcio]] president [[Massimo Cellino]] had plans to build a new stadium for the football team to play in, however the council and mayor Emilio Floris refused to give consent for the project to go ahead, despite the fact that Cellino was willing to finance the new stadium himself. Nonetheless, plans were drawn up and a draft was revealed in September 2007, with Cellino and Cagliari Calcio meeting all expenses. The project provided a stadium with 25,000 seats, with construction beginning in August 2009 and expected completion a year later. However, late in 2009, Cagliari Calcio proposed a revamped plan for the Karalis Arena in order to be added to the list of the [[Euro 2016]] candidature. The new stadium would accommodate about 30,000 spectators and have new Skybox, restaurants and café.[http://www.unionesarda.it/articoli/articolo/158887 L'Uefa approva la Karalis Arena L'impianto avrà 33mila posti – Cronache dalla Sardegna – L'Unione Sarda] Due to disagreements with the new local administration headed by mayor [[Massimo Zedda]] and growing safety concerns regarding the venue, Cagliari left Stadio Sant'Elia in the final weeks of the [[2011–12 Serie A]] season, playing the remaining few home games at [[Stadio Nereo Rocco]], [[Trieste]]. For the [[2012–13 Serie A]] season, Cagliari played its home games outside its home city, at [[Stadio Comunale Is Arenas]] in [[Quartu Sant'Elena]], thus ultimately putting an end to its long-standing association with Stadio Sant'Elia.{{cite news |url=http://www.repubblica.it/sport/calcio/serie-a/cagliari/2012/05/21/news/rivoluzione_in_arrivo_is_arenas-35653028/ |publisher=[[La Repubblica]] |language=Italian |accessdate=21 May 2012|date=21 May 2012|title=Sant'Elia addio, 'Is Arenas' è realtà Ficcadenti in bilico, chi in panchina? |trans-title=Sant'Elia goodbye, Is Arenas is reality. Ficcadenti in danger, who's going to be the next coach?}} However, Cagliari cancelled their contract at Stadio Is Arenas in April 2013 after having safety issues with local authorities all season, which forced them to play behind closed doors in several matches.{{cite news |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11872/8613682/serie-a-cagliari-cancel-contract-at-stadio-is-arenas-in-quartu-santelena|publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=2 April 2013|title=Serie A: Cagliari cancel contract at Stadio Is Arenas in Quartu Sant'Elena}} It was announced on 19 October 2013 that Cagliari would return to the Stadio Sant’Elia for the remainder of [[2013-14 Serie A]] season.{{cite news |url=http://forzaitalianfootball.com/2013/10/cagliari-will-return-to-the-stadio-santelia-for-remainder-of-season/|publisher=[[Forza Italian Football]] |date=19 October 2013|title=Cagliari will return to the Stadio Sant’Elia for remainder of season}} On 1 August 2014, after a deal with the local council, new Cagliari President Tommaso Giulini announced that Stadio Sant’Elia would be expanded to hold at least 11,650 fans for the [[2014-15 Serie A]] season. The goal was to reach a capacity of 16,000 (or even 18,000) by 21 December 2014 (home match against Juventus).{{cite news |url=http://www.sardanews.it/news/37084-sant-elia-patto-di-ferro-tra-giulini-e-zedda-nel-2020-stadio-nuovo-con-negozi-e-museo-cronache-dalla-sardegna |publisher=[[Sarda News]] |language=Italian |accessdate=1 August 2014|date=1 August 2014|title=Sant'Elia, patto di ferro tra Giulini e Zedda "Nel 2020 stadio nuovo con negozi e museo" - Cronache dalla Sardegna}} On 24 October 2014, the Provincial Supervision Committee gave the go-ahead for opening Curva Sud which has a capacity of 4,000 seats. Thus, it was expected that the stadium would have a total capacity of 16,000 when Cagliari Calcio took on AC Milan on 29 October.{{cite news |url=http://gianlucadimarzio.com/cagliari/cagliari-riaperta-la-curva-sud-del-santelia-il-comunicato/|publisher=[[Gianluca Di Marzio]] |language=Italian|accessdate=24 October 2014|date=24 October 2014|title=Cagliari, riaperta la Curva Sud del Sant’Elia: il comunicato}} On 18 December 2015 Cagliari Calcio presented a project of a new stadium which would have a capacity of 21,000, shops, and a restaurant. The project was approved by the local council on 21 February 2017 and by the region on 1 March 2017. Work started in April 2017 and the new stadium will be completed by 2020. During the construction of the new stadium Cagliari plays at the [[Sardegna Arena]], a provisional stadium built near old Sant'Elia. ==1990 FIFA World Cup== The stadium was one of the venues of the [[1990 FIFA World Cup]]. Although it was denied by local and [[FIFA]] organisers, it was widely rumoured that the stadium had been chosen for all of [[England national football team|England]]'s group matches as a way to control their reputation at the time for [[Football hooliganism|hooliganism]].[http://www.historicalkits.co.uk/international/tournaments/fifa-world-cup/1990/1990-group-f.html FIFA World Cup 1990 – Group F – Historical Football Kits] The following matches were held at the ground: {{clear}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: left;" width="100%" |- !Date !Team No. 1 !Res. !Team No. 2 !Round |- |11 June 1990||{{fb|ENG}}||style="text-align:center;"|1–1||{{fb|IRL}}||Group F |- |16 June 1990||{{fb|ENG}}||style="text-align:center;"|0–0||{{fb|NED}}||Group F |- |21 June 1990||{{fb|ENG}}||style="text-align:center;"|1–0||{{fb|EGY}}||Group F |} == References == {{Reflist}} {{World Cup 1990 stadiums}} {{Serie A venues}} {{Coord|39|11|57.82|N|9|8|5.83|E|type:landmark|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Stadio Sant'elia}} [[Category:Football venues in Italy|Sant'Elia]] [[Category:Serie A venues|Sant'Elia]] [[Category:1990 FIFA World Cup stadiums]] [[Category:Cagliari Calcio]] [[Category:Sports venues in Sardinia]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1970]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Stadium | name = Hrvatski vitezovi | nickname = | image = | fullname = Stadion Hrvatski vitezovi | location = [[Dugopolje]], [[Croatia]] | coordinates = {{coord|43|35|17|N|16|34|27|E|region:HR_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 22 July 2009 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Municipality of Dugopolje | operator = | surface = Grass | construction_cost = [[Croatian kuna|HRK]] 55M (2008) | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[NK Dugopolje]] (2009–present) | capacity = 5,200 | dimensions = | scoreboard = }}
'''Stadion Hrvatski vitezovi''' ([[English language|English]]: ''Croatian Knights Stadium'') is a [[football]] [[stadium]] in [[Dugopolje]], near the city of [[Split (city)|Split]] in southern [[Croatia]]. The stadium has a capacity of 5,200 and is home to the [[Druga HNL|second-level]] side [[NK Dugopolje]]. The stadium was officially opened on 22 July 2009, with a friendly game between Dugopolje and [[HNK Hajduk Split|Hajduk Split]].<ref name="24sata">{{cite news|url=http://www.24sata.hr/sport/dugopolje-spektakularno-otvorilo-svoj-novi-stadion/127278/|title=Dugopolje spektakularno otvorilo svoj novi stadion|last=Gabelić|first=Tomislav|date=22 July 2009|publisher=[[24 sata (Croatia)|24 sata]]|language=Croatian|accessdate=9 May 2010}}</ref>
The stadium's construction cost was 55 million [[Croatian kuna|kuna]]<ref name="slobodna">{{cite news|url=http://www.slobodnadalmacija.hr/Nogomet/tabid/84/articleType/ArticleView/articleId/28135/Default.aspx|title=U Dugopolju stadion prema uvjetima UEFA-e|last=Boban|first=Vesna|date=1 November 2008|publisher=[[Slobodna Dalmacija]]|language=Croatian|accessdate=9 May 2010}}</ref> and is part of a larger sports complex which includes club's administration buildings, several swimming pools and tennis courts.<ref name="slobodna"/>
In June 2009 the stadium was visited by [[UEFA]]'s stadium licensing inspection which gave it high marks, and approved the stadium to be used for European matches.<ref name="slobodna2">{{cite news|url=http://www.slobodnadalmacija.hr/Nogomet/tabid/84/articleType/ArticleView/articleId/57205/Default.aspx|title=UEFA oduševljena stadionom u Dugopolju|date=5 June 2009|publisher=[[Slobodna Dalmacija]]|language=Croatian|accessdate=9 May 2010}}</ref>
It was confirmed in May 2010 that [[HNK Šibenik]], Croatian top-level side which had secured their European debut at the end of the [[2009–10 Prva HNL|2009–10 season]], will host their European matches in the following season at Dugopolje's ground, since their own [[Stadion Šubićevac]] did not meet UEFA licensing requirements.<ref name="dulibic">{{cite news|url=http://www.sportnet.hr/vijesti/396817/nogomet-1-hnl/dulibic-idemo-u-europu-u-dugopolje|title=Dulibić: "Idemo u Europu u Dugopolje"|last=Jurica|first=Ivana|date=9 May 2010|publisher=[[Sportnet.hr]]|language=Croatian|accessdate=9 May 2010}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

at the Summer Olympics|Rugby sevens]], * [[Sailing at the Summer Olympics|Sailing]], * [[Shooting at the Summer Olympics|Shooting]], *[[Surfing at the Summer Olympics|Surfing]], * [[Swimming at the
